fields.bio_summary: Stephen Joseph Harper (born April 30, 1959) is a Canadian politician who is the 22nd and current Prime Minister of Canada and the Leader of the Conservative Party. Harper became prime minister in 2006, forming a minority government after the 2006 election. He is the first prime minister to come from the newly reconstituted Conservative Party, which formed after a merger of the Progressive Conservative Party and the Canadian Alliance.

fields.operations_summary:
Stephen Harper’s Conservative Government is focused on the priorities of Canadians – job creation and economic growth.
With the support of our Economic Action Plan, the Canadian economy has created approximately one million net new jobs since the depths of the global economic recession.  While the job isn’t done yet, this job creation record is the best in the G7 and shows that Canada is on the right track.

fields.text: Hey thanks.  I stopped editing because I realized that C-13 got royal assent, and then started to focus on C-51.  It's worth finishing though, just for the record.  I wonder if we should have a way to indicate that a given issue corresponds to a bill, and whether that bill is still being read in parliament?...

This report compares Anti-terrorism legislation in the UK and the Netherlands: http://www.icct.nl/download/file/ICCT-Eijkman-Preventative-CT-and-Non-Discrimination-EU-July-2011.pdf I do see some similarities to Bill C-51: "This Act allows the police to search suspects without requiring
concrete suspicion of a crime, broadened their ability to utilise ‘special investigative powers’ and made it possible
for people suspected of terrorism?related offences to be held in custody for up to 27 months. A key concept of
the amendments to the criminal procedural code was that the police no longer required ‘suspicions of a terrorist
crime’ but could act upon ‘indications of a terrorist crime’, a considerably lower threshold standard of evidence." A more thorough read of this report will probably be insightful.
Hmm.. ok.  But does the average non-self-directed TFSA account actually makes enough interest for there to be any real tax benefits.

So, for the average non-savvy Canadian investor a non-self-directed TFSA is sort of like investing with training wheels? You aren't going to get going very fast (make huge profits), but neither will you fall and scrape your knee (pay the financial blowback for not getting a capital loss tax-credit)? Does this make the laymen's use for them a sort of exercise in peddling and keeping your balance (financial discipline and strategy 101)?
Hey -- good question!  I have no idea.  But maybe we can investigate.  Why don't we narrow it down to certain countries to look at.  Do you have any in mind?
Welcome to luminocracy!  We appreciate your participation!  However, the purpose of this area is to ask questions directly related to the issue, namely Canada's involvement in Syria.
Well said.

What is suggested here is a powerful counter-argument to the criminalisation of terrorist propaganda. However, I believe that the letter would be stronger and more straightforward if no reference was made to the preferred effectiveness of counter-speech. I believe that petitions are stronger when they express one and only one strong argument at a time. Further, if the counter-speech element is to stay, I think it would benefit from being better unpacked. I do support the idea, though! :)

Acknowledging the difficulty in assigning an "endpoint" to such an unpredictable series of dynamics, it is nonetheless important to have transparent, definitive, and respected committal period (of military spending that is). I would suggest appending the letter to reflect this importance. If not to avoid some potential for what the summary addresses in the danger Canada's abrupt and unannounced withdrawal, then at least to avoid runaway government expenditure in addition to/as a result of economic and political opportunism that often occurs and thrives in times and places of strife and war. While such an overt statement of intended committed action time can afford belligerents a tactical advantage, it could be minimized by making the committed endpoint broad. I.e. Committing to withdrawing military spending/activity DEFINITELY by xx/xx/2017. Inasmuch that the termination date is established as March 2016, it seemingly stands only as a placeholder for when the next vote may be to extend the military presence/spending, and as has been seen in the past military spending often outlives its projected shelf life.

It definitely seems like there is no clear endpoint, and I agree that the March 2016 is really just putting off the decision until then.  I would definitely support a letter whose goal is to establish a clear endpoint.  We should really decide what exactly it is we're trying to achieve there!

Agreed. I suppose the simple answer is that we are trying to preserve human life. Is the best way to do that, in this situation that is, to become another future empty space in the Syrian political-power vacuum though? I honestly have no clue. With that being said it seems that this petition has the best chance of yielding some kind of positive result out of the inevitability of military action.

This article lists similar legislation in France, Australia and Britain: http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/terrorism-a-look-at-what-other-countries-have-done-to-combat-the-threat-1.2938379

Further research is needed to give more examples.

With a TFSA both the reward and the risk impact are amplified. If you make $100,000 from your TFSA investment, you have made more than with any other account because there is no tax on this profit. However, if you lose the money you contributed then you cannot claim tax deduction for capital loss and you also lose the contribution room.  Thus, a self-directed TFSA makes sense for very knowledgeable investors and traders, who have high confidence that the investments will generate positive return. The interest for a currency account may also be of advantageous to wealthy Canadians who can continuously make the maximum allowed contributions and benefit from compounding.
To answer your question: the incentive for a non-self-directed TFSA is primarily for the average Canadian who is not a knowledgeable investor and for whom a loss in a TFSA costs much more than a loss in RRSP or in a regular investment account.

Acording to [this source](http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/policy-analysis/view/explaining-the-turkish-militarys-opposition-to-combating-isis), there is somewhat of an internal power struggle between the Turkish government and the Turkish military.  Also, in a policy disliked by the military, the government has pursued peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers Party, whose fighters have killed thousands of military personel.  The dislike of the military toward Kurds makes them reluctant to fight beside them against ISIS.  The Turkish also (allegedly) feel limited sympathy for Arabs, especially among the military, making them less motivated to get involved.  Finally, this source suggests that the Turkish military might be worried that engaging ISIS would reveal that it has technical and tactical weaknesses.

These reasons make it more complicated, politically, for Turkey to become involved.  It probably should concern other NATO members that Turkey is not involved in fighting ISIS.  At the same time, Turkey may be less likely to respond to pressure from it's peers to engage in the fight.
Isis is a great name for a boy *cat*.  Don't use it for boy human its bad cause ISIS is bad.

fields.title: Other examples needed?
fields.text:
Relative to France, the US, Australia, and Britain, Canada's anti-terrorism legislation is "less invasive".[4]
Qs: I am wondering if there are other examples of this kind of bill, say from Northern European or other countries, and how the Canadian bill compares with these. What would constitute an ideal anti-terrorism bill?

fields.title: Incentive for a non-self-directed TFSA?
fields.text: Is there any incentive to hold currency in a TFSA?  I have currency in an account, there's generally no significant interest to speak of.  So, there is really nothing to be taxed, and no benefit of having the money in in a TFSA.  It seems to me that the only TFSA that makes sense is a self-directed one, where the funds are invested in some revenue-generating instrument.  Am I missing something?

fields.title: Why are Turkish forces not fighting in Syria?
fields.text: Turkey being a fellow NATO member, and also the only NATO member who shares a border with Syria, doesn't appear to be involved in the fight. Shouldn't this concern other NATO members?

fields.title: The name ISIS
fields.text:
Do you think Isis is a good name for a boy?

I used to think it was a really lovely name, but now it has some bad connotations .

Anyone have any better ideas?

fields.title: What is our role in any foreign conflict?
fields.text:
Throughout my life, I have witnessed Canada's international duties shift from peacekeeping to war-making. Recently, we seem to quietly follow America in their real-life game of Risk. Just like wars against Iraq, Afghanistan, and even Germany, there are valid reasons to intervene, and innocent people in genuine need. However, intervention also provides many opportunities for personal gain, for those behind the figurative dashboard, whose hands will only only touch blood that is also figurative, while those they have commanded spill theirs literally.

Most of my friends from Iraq and Afghanistan are greatly appreciative that other countries have stepped in to the supposed rescue. Although, there has been a clear increase in terrorism within our borders, since we began fighting more actively beyond them.

Personally, I am not certain whether or not resolution can be achieved without violence, but how does that old saying go? An eye for an eye until... everything works out!

fields.title: Remove criminalization of terrorist propoganda from Bill C-51
fields.text:
With rapid communication, and the potential to mobilize quickly, I acknowledge the need to update the tools available to protect Canadians from terrorist threats.

I believe, however, that these threats must be treated proportionately, and, above all, effectively.

Criminalizing propaganda misses the target, which is to prevent violence.  This will only drive those who would wish to do harm underground, and further alienate them.  A focus on counter-speech would be much more effective.

The freedom of speech is an important mechanism, not only for democracy, but for the health of society in general. Societal tensions and problems can be more productively addressed when they are visible on the surface.

Please remove those sections from Bill C-51 that criminalize terrorist propopanda.

fields.title: Stop Keystone XL
fields.text: I do not support the project to expand the Keystone Pipeline System.  This proposal generates serious and certain  environmental losses, which do not justify the economic gains.  Furthermore, the development will bring wealth mainly to foreign shareholders, so that the actual economic gains will be much less than they should  be.

fields.title: Harper: match military spending with humanitarian aid for Iraq and Syria
fields.text:
I support the government's decision to join the coalition effort to fight ISIL, and I am proud of our zero civilian casualty policy.

However, as Mr. Mulcair has pointed out, providing humanitarian aid is key to the effectiveness of the intervention.

According to one source, Canada has spent $122 M in the form of military activity in Iraq in the past six moths.  Show your commitment to the long-term resolution of this conflict by making a commitment to match all military spending with an equal amount of humanitarian aid.

fields.title: Net Neutrality
fields.text:
#Background#
The term Net Neutrality was originally coined by professor Tim Wu in 2003 (http://www.jthtl.org/content/articles/V2I1/JTHTLv2i1_Wu.PDF). However, the debate on Net Neutrality was ongoing prior to that. Advocates for Net Neutrality are concerned that ISPs may use their control over the network infrastructure to block or otherwise deteriorate access to content, services or websites which are competitors to, or deemed undesirable by, the ISP.
Critics of Net Neutrality claim that network management is needed in order to ensure Quality of Service and to prioritize critical applications such as VoIP telephony or email, over less critical ones, like peer-to-peer networks.

# Actors #
 - **Internet Service Providers**: Companies which connect retail customers to the Internet. Examples include Comcast, AT&T, Time Warner Cable, Rogers, etc.
 - **Transit Service Providers**: Companies, sometimes ISPs or hosting providers, which interconnect ISPs. They are responsible for the backbone of the Internet. When content moves from a hosting provider to an ISP, the Transit Service Providers may collect fees. Examples include Cogent Communications, Hurricane Electric, Level 3 Communications, etc.
 - **Established Content Providers**: Include Netflix, Amazon, Google, etc. These are large companies, responsible for the majority of content carried over the Internet.
 - **Government**: The Government can impose a law on ISPs, requiring Net Neutrality. The main interest of the government is to ensure fair access to content, while promoting economic activity.
 - **Alternative Content Providers**: Services like Vimeo, Mega, Popcorn Time and other emerging providers. They may be unable to enter in agreements with ISPs due to lack of funding or legal impediments.
 - **Internet Users**: Ordinary people want to maximize their access to content and connection quality, while keeping prices low.

# Impacts #
## Social Impacts ##
**Content Monopoly**. Alternative content providers are concerned that ISPs may use their control over the network to “lock-out” competing services or those unable to enter into traffic shaping agreements.

**Censorship**. Internet users are worry of the impact that control over access to content may have on democracy and freedoms.

**Quality of Service**. Internet providers claim that some popular content providers cause saturation of the network and degrade the Internet service for all users. Some users are concerned that degraded network performance may impact essential communications services such as access to 911 over VoIP lines.

**Inequality**. Some content providers claim that the design of Internet protocols already imposes inequality by favouring non time-sensitive applications, such as large file downloads, over real time services like VoIP or multiplayer games. They argue that network management techniques level the playing field for time-sensitive applications.

## Economic Impacts ##
**Internet Service Innovations**. ISPs are concerned that a few content providers utilize most of the available network bandwidth without paying a proportional access fee. Thus, they claim that further innovations in Internet services would be hindered unless tiered Internet access is introduced.

**“Double dipping”**. Some content providers are worried that without Net Neutrality ISPs may charge twice for transmitting the same content: once as Transit Service Providers when content leaves the source, and a second time as ISPs when content reaches the subscriber.

**Tiered service**. Consumers are concerned that, without Net Neutrality, ISPs may introduce tiered service requiring them to pay extra for access to the content they are already subscribing to.

**Interference with free market**. Critics of Net Neutrality claim that government intervention impacts the free market’s ability to reach price equilibrium based on supply and demand at the various levels of service quality.

# In Perspective #
- Some providers in the developing world offer what is known as “Free Zones”, meaning that content providers have entered in an agreement with the ISP to cover fees associated with accessing the content over the ISP’s network (Lily Hay Newman (21 Jan 2014). "Net Neutrality Is Already in Trouble in the Developing World". Slate. Retrieved 18 Nov 2014).

- In December 2009, a major US ISP (Comcast) admitted to applying traffic shaping practices against BitTorrent traffic on its network and agreed to pay up to $16 Million USD as a settlement (Duncan, Geoff (23 December 2009). "Comcast to Pay $16 Million for Blocking P2P Applications". Digital Trends. Retrieved 23 December 2009.)

- The French ISP Orange has reached an agreement with Google, which stipulates that Google reimburses Orange for YouTube traffic (which amounts to about 50% of all traffic on the Orange network) (Robertson, Adi (2013-01-19). "French ISP Orange says it's making Google pay to send traffic over its network". The Verge. Retrieved 14 January 2014.)

- Some services, like Xbox gaming and IPTV, already receive preferential treatment over the network of US ISP Comcast. (Brendan Greeley (21 Jun 2012). "Comcast 'Invents' Its Own Private Internet". Bloomberg. Retrieved 18 Nov 2014.)

- Netflix, a major US video content provider, has established peering agreements with US ISPs Comcast and Verizon. It is debatable whether peering agreements are a violation of Net Neutrality, however they were reached in response to deteriorated performance of access to Netflix content over the ISPs’ networks. (Waniata, Ryan. "Comcast Jumps up in Netflix Speed Rankings after Payola-style Agreement." Digital Trends. N.p., 14 Apr. 2014. Web. 15 Aug. 2014.) (Waniata, Ryan. "Netflix Calls Verizon out on the Big Red Screen [Update: Netflix Backs Off]." Digital Trends. N.p., 9 June 2014. Web. 15 Aug. 2014.)
fields.summary:
Net Neutrality is a principle requiring Internet Service Providers (ISP) to treat all content on the Internet equally (http://web.archive.org/web/20080901084929/http://www.google.com/help/netneutrality.html). ISPs may not apply traffic shaping or other network management techniques based on the type of content or the parties that are exchanging it. Proponents of Net Neutrality claim that in this respect it is similar to a telephone call: a phone company must treat all calls equally, regardless of what is being said or by whom.
There is a debate, particularly in the United States, whether the government should enact the Net Neutrality principle as a law.

- Netflix, a major US video content provider, has established peering agreements with US ISPs Comcast and Verizon. It is debatable whether peering agreements are a violation of Net Neutrality, however they were reached in response to deteriorated performance of access to Netflix content over the ISPs’ networks. (Waniata, Ryan. "Comcast Jumps up in Netflix Speed Rankings after Payola-style Agreement." Digital Trends. N.p., 14 Apr. 2014. Web. 15 Aug. 2014.) (Waniata, Ryan. "Netflix Calls Verizon out on the Big Red Screen [Update: Netflix Backs Off]." Digital Trends. N.p., 9 June 2014. Web. 15 Aug. 2014.)
fields.summary:
Net Neutrality is a principle requiring Internet Service Providers (ISP) to treat all content on the Internet equally (http://web.archive.org/web/20080901084929/http://www.google.com/help/netneutrality.html). ISPs may not apply traffic shaping or other network management techniques based on the type of content or the parties that are exchanging it. Proponents of Net Neutrality claim that in this respect it is similar to a telephone call: a phone company must treat all calls equally, regardless of what is being said or by whom.
There is a debate, particularly in the United States, whether the government should enact the Net Neutrality principle as a law.

fields.title: Bill C-13, Protecting Canadians from Online Crime Act
fields.text:
# Background #
A central nominal goal of Bill C-13 is to criminalize cyberbullying [1], which the Canadian Bar Association identifies as an 'Obvious legislative "gap"' [1]. In order to collect data, authorities must suspect that a crime has or will be committed, and that the information will assist in the crime's investigation. 

The bill establishes (in section 162.1) that sharing "intimate images" of a person, when the person in the image has not consented to the sharing, is an offense punishable by imprisonment for not more than 5 years.  Although the bill has been described (by Peter MacKay) as intended to protect children and youth from online predators, existing Criminal Code provisions (section 163.1 - Child Pornography) already criminalize the mere posession of such images, with harsher penalty.  Therefore, this bill only extends the provisions against the use of intimate images involving adults [1].

Section 162.1 also does not establish the need for malicious intent.  This means that in a hypothetical situation where Mr. Smith lends his laptop to Mr. Jones, Mr. Smith might be liable for having shared intimate images of him and his wife, even though they are in a deep folder marked "private", and he did not think that Mr. Jones would look there [1]. Other possibilities exist, and arise wording in section 162.1 which permits wide interpretation [1].  This also exposes the media, such as photojournalists, to criminal sanction for publishing compromising images of celebrities or politicians [1].

The Bar proposed other amendments to encourage a focus on cyberbullying and proportionate sentencing [1].  Further, they warn against excessive reliance on law to handle cyberbullying committed by youth, which may be less effective than education and other preventative measures [1]. 

Bill C-13 goes far beyond cyberbullying, and instead describes provisions for the search and seizure of Internet Data, revisiting "lawful access" legislation, which has previously been controversial [1].  The Canadian Bar Association recommended splitting the Bill into two bills, one which addresses cyberbullying, and the other to address lawful access legislation.

# Actors #
- CSEC
- Government of Canada

# Impacts #
## Culture ##
- The criminalization of cyberbullying would enable law enforcement to take action against people committing cyberbullying, and might reduce its prevalence.u 

# References #
[1] Commentary by the Canadian Bar Association ([pdf](http://www.google.ca/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=4&ved=0CDQQFjAD&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cba.org%2Fcba%2Fsubmissions%2Fpdf%2F14-33-eng.pdf&ei=Lk3cVJm9DoagNuCTgbAG&usg=AFQjCNHfIQ7iJmSssJ-kyhHJvOqwUoLRGg&sig2=A7dmQIKgYQnp9SzNteMAOw&bvm=bv.85761416,d.eXY))

fields.title: Bill C-13, Protecting Canadians from Online Crime Act
fields.text:
# Background #
A central nominal goal of Bill C-13 is to criminalize cyberbullying [1], which the Canadian Bar Association identifies as an 'Obvious legislative "gap"' [1]. In order to collect data, authorities must suspect that a crime has or will be committed, and that the information will assist in the crime's investigation. 

The bill establishes (in section 162.1) that sharing "intimate images" of a person, when the person in the image has not consented to the sharing, is an offense punishable by imprisonment for not more than 5 years.  Although the bill has been described (by Peter MacKay) as intended to protect children and youth from online predators, existing Criminal Code provisions (section 163.1 - Child Pornography) already criminalize the mere posession of such images, with harsher penalty.  Therefore, this bill only extends the provisions against the use of intimate images involving adults [1].

Section 162.1 also does not establish the need for malicious intent.  This means that in a hypothetical situation where Mr. Smith lends his laptop to Mr. Jones, Mr. Smith might be liable for having shared intimate images of him and his wife, even though they are in a deep folder marked "private", and he did not think that Mr. Jones would look there [1]. Other possibilities exist, and arise wording in section 162.1 which permits wide interpretation [1].  This also exposes the media, such as photojournalists, to criminal sanction for publishing compromising images of celebrities or politicians [1].

The Bar proposed other amendments to encourage a focus on cyberbullying and proportionate sentencing [1].  Further, they warn against excessive reliance on law to handle cyberbullying committed by youth, which may be less effective than education and other preventative measures [1]. 

Bill C-13 goes far beyond cyberbullying, and instead describes provisions for the search and seizure of Internet Data, revisiting "lawful access" legislation, which has previously been controversial [1].  The Canadian Bar Association recommended splitting the Bill into two bills, one which addresses cyberbullying, and the other to address lawful access legislation.

The Canadian Association of the Bar acknowledges the concern of the Canadian Government, but has recommended that enhancements to state power which infringe on privacy should be coupled with effective oversight mechanisms. [1]

Section 487.012 provides the power for police officers to make "preservation demands", without any judicial authorization, which requires a person to preserve (i.e. not delete) data, if the officer has reasonable grounds to suspect that a crime has or will be committed, and that the data will assist in the investigation, or that a crime under any Foreign law has or will be committed.  In the case of crimes in Canada, preservation would be for 21 days, while for foreign laws, for 90 days.  The CBA recommended reducing these periods to only cover a reasonable amount of time needed to get judicial authorization, and that preservation demands should only be applicable for crimes according to foreign laws which would also be crimes in Canada.  The Act does not require written records to be kept. (CBA recommends this be required.)

Subsection 5 of 487.012 gives officers the ability to impose unlimited conditions on preservation demands.  According to CBA, such conditions could prevent a party from exercising lawful rights, and such restrictions should only be imposed by a court of competent jurisdiction.

# Actors #
- CSEC
- Government of Canada

# Impacts #
## Culture ##
- The criminalization of cyberbullying would enable law enforcement to take action against people committing cyberbullying, and might reduce its prevalence.u 

# References #
[1] Commentary by the Canadian Bar Association ([pdf](http://www.google.ca/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=4&ved=0CDQQFjAD&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cba.org%2Fcba%2Fsubmissions%2Fpdf%2F14-33-eng.pdf&ei=Lk3cVJm9DoagNuCTgbAG&usg=AFQjCNHfIQ7iJmSssJ-kyhHJvOqwUoLRGg&sig2=A7dmQIKgYQnp9SzNteMAOw&bvm=bv.85761416,d.eXY))

fields.title: Bill C-13, Protecting Canadians from Online Crime Act
fields.text:
# Background #
A central nominal goal of Bill C-13 is to criminalize cyberbullying [1], which the Canadian Bar Association identifies as an 'Obvious legislative "gap"' [1]. In order to collect data, authorities must suspect that a crime has or will be committed, and that the information will assist in the crime's investigation. 

The bill establishes (in section 162.1) that sharing "intimate images" of a person, when the person in the image has not consented to the sharing, is an offense punishable by imprisonment for not more than 5 years.  Although the bill has been described (by Peter MacKay) as intended to protect children and youth from online predators, existing Criminal Code provisions (section 163.1 - Child Pornography) already criminalize the mere posession of such images, with harsher penalty.  Therefore, this bill only extends the provisions against the use of intimate images involving adults [1].

Section 162.1 also does not establish the need for malicious intent.  This means that in a hypothetical situation where Mr. Smith lends his laptop to Mr. Jones, Mr. Smith might be liable for having shared intimate images of him and his wife, even though they are in a deep folder marked "private", and he did not think that Mr. Jones would look there [1]. Other possibilities exist, and arise wording in section 162.1 which permits wide interpretation [1].  This also exposes the media, such as photojournalists, to criminal sanction for publishing compromising images of celebrities or politicians [1].

The Bar proposed other amendments to encourage a focus on cyberbullying and proportionate sentencing [1].  Further, they warn against excessive reliance on law to handle cyberbullying committed by youth, which may be less effective than education and other preventative measures [1]. 

Bill C-13 goes far beyond cyberbullying, and instead describes provisions for the search and seizure of Internet Data, revisiting "lawful access" legislation, which has previously been controversial [1].  The Canadian Bar Association recommended splitting the Bill into two bills, one which addresses cyberbullying, and the other to address lawful access legislation.

The Canadian Association of the Bar acknowledges the concern of the Canadian Government, but has recommended that enhancements to state power which infringe on privacy should be coupled with effective oversight mechanisms. [1]

Section 487.012 provides the power for police officers to make "preservation demands", without any judicial authorization, which requires a person to preserve (i.e. not delete) data, if the officer has reasonable grounds to suspect that a crime has or will be committed, and that the data will assist in the investigation, or that a crime under any Foreign law has or will be committed.  In the case of crimes in Canada, preservation would be for 21 days, while for foreign laws, for 90 days.  The CBA recommended reducing these periods to only cover a reasonable amount of time needed to get judicial authorization, and that preservation demands should only be applicable for crimes according to foreign laws which would also be crimes in Canada.  The Act does not require written records to be kept. (CBA recommends this be required.)

Subsection 5 of 487.012 gives officers the ability to impose unlimited conditions on preservation demands.  According to CBA, such conditions could prevent a party from exercising lawful rights, and such restrictions should only be imposed by a court of competent jurisdiction.

The bill empowers judges to issue production orders for tracking data (such as GPS data), information identifying financial account holders, and the use of tracking devices, but with a lower threshold than previously existed -- 
only requiring that the judge be satisfied that there are reasonable grounds to *suspect* (as opposed to believe) that on offense has or will be committed.

Section 492.2 updates laws which enabled officers to obtain telephone metadata to allow law enforcement to install "transmission data recorders" to capture metadata related to any kind of telecommunications.  Because of the richness of digital telecommunications, this could identify far more detailed biographical information about the individual, and so is a materially more severe invasion of privacy.  Warrants to use a transmission data recorder also only need to be justified by reasonable grounds to *suspect* (as opposed to believe) that an offense has or will be committed.  Information that could be captured would include

 - the IP address of the originating computer and server (i.e. website) being communicated with
 - the computer program being used
 - the protocol being used (identifying whether the person is viewing a website, using videoconferencing, etc)
 - whether the transmission was completed

This would enable, for example, to tell whether a person had been communicating on a regular basis with a particular health professional, or accessing a particular online service.

# Actors #
- CSEC
- Government of Canada

# Impacts #
## Culture ##
- The criminalization of cyberbullying would enable law enforcement to take action against people committing cyberbullying, and might reduce its prevalence.u 

# References #
[1] Commentary by the Canadian Bar Association ([pdf](http://www.google.ca/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=4&ved=0CDQQFjAD&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cba.org%2Fcba%2Fsubmissions%2Fpdf%2F14-33-eng.pdf&ei=Lk3cVJm9DoagNuCTgbAG&usg=AFQjCNHfIQ7iJmSssJ-kyhHJvOqwUoLRGg&sig2=A7dmQIKgYQnp9SzNteMAOw&bvm=bv.85761416,d.eXY))

fields.title: Bill C-51
fields.text:
# Background #
 - Bill C-51 contains a section that gives the government the power to order Internet Service Providers (ISPs) or website administrators to remove content if a judge deems the material to be "terrorist propoganda" [1]
 - For comparison, existing legislation allows ordering the removal of "hate propoganda" and child pornography. [1]
 - The department of justice says that this is similar to legislation existing in UK and Australia. [1]
 - Such legislation can have a "chilling effect", wherein people sensor themselves because they are afriad their words might be misconstrued.[1]
 - In June 2014, the Supreme Court ruled that a warrant is required for law enforcement to obtain identifying information about Canadians from ISPs. [1][2][3]
 - It is unclear how expansive "terrorrist propoganda" is.  It may be possible for artistic expression and political dissent to be construed as terrorist propoganda, interfearing with open dialogue and expression.[1] 
 - allows CSIS to disrupt terrorist activities, to pre-empt or prevent, e.g. financial transaction, CSIS could compel the diversion of materials [4], within or outside Canada (expansion of mandate).
 - Preventative detention if they may commit a terrorist attack "may"

# In perspective #
 - In the UK in 2010 more than 65,000 pieces of unlawful terrorist related content was removed, 80% of which was jihadist groups from Iraq and Syria[1]
 - In the UK, the government reached an agreement with ISPs to voluntarily block content from outside the UK, at the request of the UK counterterrorism unit, without court order, while the law enables the government to compel hosts in the UK to remove content.[1] 
 - In Australia ISPs and websites can be compelled to remove content and action can be taken against them if they refuse.  For content outside the country, the ASIO or federal police can order ISPs or websites to block the content, without court order.[1]
 - The UK has no requirement for public disclosure about how often and what content is blocked / removed. [1]

# References #
[1] http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/bill-c-51-aims-to-remove-terrorist-propaganda-from-internet-1.2938935 
[2] http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/internet-users-privacy-upheld-by-canada-s-top-court-1.2673823
[3] http://scc-csc.lexum.com/scc-csc/scc-csc/en/item/14233/index.do
[4] http://www.cbc.ca/player/News/Politics/Power+%26+Politics/ID/2651124680/
fields.summary: Bill C-51 provides new powers to CSIS to counter terrorism by pre-emptively interfearing with the transfer of funds or the delivery of materials.  It introduces the power for the government, with judicial approval, to compel Internet Service Providers (ISPs) or websites to remove terrorist material.

 - In June 2014, the Supreme Court ruled that a warrant is required for law enforcement to obtain identifying information about Canadians from ISPs. [1][2][3]
 - It is unclear how expansive "terrorrist propoganda" is.  It may be possible for artistic expression and political dissent to be construed as terrorist propoganda, interfearing with open dialogue and expression.[1] 
 - allows CSIS to disrupt terrorist activities, to pre-empt or prevent, e.g. financial transaction, CSIS could compel the diversion of materials [4], within or outside Canada (expansion of mandate).
 - Preventative detention if they may commit a terrorist attack "may"

# In perspective #
 - In the UK in 2010 more than 65,000 pieces of unlawful terrorist related content was removed, 80% of which was jihadist groups from Iraq and Syria[1]
 - In the UK, the government reached an agreement with ISPs to voluntarily block content from outside the UK, at the request of the UK counterterrorism unit, without court order, while the law enables the government to compel hosts in the UK to remove content.[1] 
 - In Australia ISPs and websites can be compelled to remove content and action can be taken against them if they refuse.  For content outside the country, the ASIO or federal police can order ISPs or websites to block the content, without court order.[1]
 - The UK has no requirement for public disclosure about how often and what content is blocked / removed. [1]

# References #
[1] http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/bill-c-51-aims-to-remove-terrorist-propaganda-from-internet-1.2938935 
[2] http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/internet-users-privacy-upheld-by-canada-s-top-court-1.2673823

# Background #
 - Bill C-51 contains a section that gives the government the power to order Internet Service Providers (ISPs) or website administrators to remove content if a judge deems the material to be "terrorist propoganda" [1]
 - For comparison, existing legislation allows ordering the removal of "hate propoganda" and child pornography. [1]

 - It is unclear how expansive "terrorrist propoganda" is.  It may be possible for artistic expression and political dissent to be construed as terrorist propoganda, interfearing with open dialogue and expression.[1]

 - In the UK in 2010 more than 65,000 pieces of unlawful terrorist related content was removed, 80% of which was jihadist groups from Iraq and Syria[1]
 - In the UK, the government reached an agreement with ISPs to voluntarily block content from outside the UK, at the request of the UK counterterrorism unit, without court order, while the law enables the government to compel hosts in the UK to remove content.[1] 
 - In Australia ISPs and websites can be compelled to remove content and action can be taken against them if they refuse.  For content outside the country, the ASIO or federal police can order ISPs or websites to block the content, without court order.[1]
 - The UK has no requirement for public disclosure about how often and what content is blocked / removed. [1]

fields.title: Bill C-51
fields.text:
# Background #
 - Bill C-51 contains a section that gives the government the power to order Internet Service Providers (ISPs) or website administrators to remove content if a judge deems the material to be "terrorist propoganda" [1]
 - For comparison, existing legislation allows ordering the removal of "hate propoganda" and child pornography. [1]
 - The department of justice says that this is similar to legislation existing in UK and Australia. [1]
 - In June 2014, the Supreme Court ruled that a warrant is required for law enforcement to obtain identifying information about Canadians from ISPs. [1][2][3]
 - It is unclear how expansive "terrorrist propoganda" is.  It may be possible for artistic expression and political dissent to be construed as terrorist propoganda, interfearing with open dialogue and expression.[1] 
 - CSIS currently only has the ability to investigate, and must pass information to the RCMP who can act on it.  The bill would give CSIS the power to actively interfere with terrorist plots, by [4]:
    - cancelling travel reservations made by suspected extremists
    - blocking shipments to Canada of material that could be used in a terrorist attack
    - rendering shipments of suspected terrorist-related material unusable.
 
# Impacts #
## Readiness #
 - Allowing CSIS to use the information it has to take action to prevent terrorist plots will reduce the response time. 

## Democracy ##
 - By lowering the standard of evidence, the new laws may lead to self-sensorship or undue surveillance of those expressing political dissent. [1]

## Culture ##
 - Material considered to be "terrorist propoganda" could be essentially removed from the Internet normally accessible to Canadians.
 - Political and artistic expression, near the fringe, may be self-sensored, since it is not clear what constitutes "terrorist propoganda".


# In perspective #
 - In the UK in 2010 more than 65,000 pieces of unlawful terrorist related content was removed, 80% of which was jihadist groups from Iraq and Syria[1]
 - In the UK, the government reached an agreement with ISPs to voluntarily block content from outside the UK, at the request of the UK counterterrorism unit, without court order, while the law enables the government to compel hosts in the UK to remove content.[1] 
 - In Australia ISPs and websites can be compelled to remove content and action can be taken against them if they refuse.  For content outside the country, the ASIO or federal police can order ISPs or websites to block the content, without court order.[1]
 - The UK has no requirement for public disclosure about how often and what content is blocked / removed. [1]
 - Relative to France, the US, Australia, and Britain, Canada's anti-terrorism legislation is less invasive.[4]

# References #
[1] [CBC. Bill C-51 aims to 'remove terrorist propaganda' from internet](http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/bill-c-51-aims-to-remove-terrorist-propaganda-from-internet-1.2938935)  
[2] [CBC. Internet users' privacy upheld by Canada's top court](http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/internet-users-privacy-upheld-by-canada-s-top-court-1.2673823)  
[3] [Supreme Court judgment: R v. Spensor](http://scc-csc.lexum.com/scc-csc/scc-csc/en/item/14233/index.do)  
[4] [The National Post. *S.A. McCartan: Virtually all of Canada’s allies give their spy agencies powers to prevent terror. Why not us?*](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/03/s-a-mccartan-virtually-all-of-canadas-allies-give-their-spy-agencies-powers-to-prevent-terror-why-not-us/)

fields.text:

 - The department of justice says that this is similar to legislation existing in UK and Australia. [1]
 - In June 2014, the Supreme Court ruled that a warrant is required for law enforcement to obtain identifying information about Canadians from ISPs. [1][2][3]
 - It is unclear how expansive "terrorrist propoganda" is.  It may be possible for artistic expression and political dissent to be construed as terrorist propoganda, interfearing with open dialogue and expression.[1] 
 - CSIS currently only has the ability to investigate, and must pass information to the RCMP who can act on it.  The bill would give CSIS the power to actively interfere with terrorist plots, by [4]:
    - cancelling travel reservations made by suspected extremists
    - blocking shipments to Canada of material that could be used in a terrorist attack
    - rendering shipments of suspected terrorist-related material unusable.
 
 - The bill prohibits "advocating" or "promoting" terrorism, although the definition of these terms is not given.

# Impacts #
## Readiness #
 - Allowing CSIS to use the information it has to take action to prevent terrorist plots will reduce the response time.

 - By lowering the standard of evidence, the new laws may lead to self-sensorship or undue surveillance of those expressing political dissent. [1]

 - Political and artistic expression, near the fringe, may be self-sensored, since it is not clear what constitutes "terrorist propoganda". [1]
 - The uncertainty created by the law may make it more difficult for law enforcement to engage with people who are suspected to be susceptible to radicalization, because they may believe they will be found guilty for their beliefs. [5]

 - In the UK in 2010 more than 65,000 pieces of unlawful terrorist related content was removed, 80% of which was jihadist groups from Iraq and Syria[1]
 - In the UK, the government reached an agreement with ISPs to voluntarily block content from outside the UK, at the request of the UK counterterrorism unit, without court order, while the law enables the government to compel hosts in the UK to remove content.[1]

 - Relative to France, the US, Australia, and Britain, Canada's anti-terrorism legislation is less invasive.[4]

[4] [The National Post. *S.A. McCartan: Virtually all of Canada’s allies give their spy agencies powers to prevent terror. Why not us?*](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/03/s-a-mccartan-virtually-all-of-canadas-allies-give-their-spy-agencies-powers-to-prevent-terror-why-not-us/)

fields.title: Bill C-51
fields.text:
# Background #
 - The RCMP runs a counter-violent extremism (CVE) program, which attempts to connect with people who hold radical views and prevent them from becoming violent.[5] 
 - Bill C-51 contains a section that gives the government the power to order Internet Service Providers (ISPs) or website administrators to remove content if a judge deems the material to be "terrorist propoganda" [1]
 - Bill C-51 targets activity that "undermines the security of Canada" by interfering with federal capabilities in relation to the country's economic or "financial stability" [5]
 - By rendering the promotion / advocacy of terrorist propoganda illegal, a valuable source of intelligence will be suppressed, driving actual terrorist plots underground. [5]
 - For comparison, existing legislation allows ordering the removal of "hate propoganda" and child pornography. [1]
 - The department of justice says that this is similar to legislation existing in UK and Australia. [1]
 - In June 2014, the Supreme Court ruled that a warrant is required for law enforcement to obtain identifying information about Canadians from ISPs. [1][2][3]
 - It is unclear how expansive "terrorrist propoganda" is.  It may be possible for artistic expression and political dissent to be construed as terrorist propoganda, interfearing with open dialogue and expression.[1] 
 - CSIS currently only has the ability to investigate, and must pass information to the RCMP who can act on it.  The bill would give CSIS the power to actively interfere with terrorist plots, by [4]:
    - cancelling travel reservations made by suspected extremists
    - blocking shipments to Canada of material that could be used in a terrorist attack
    - rendering shipments of suspected terrorist-related material unusable.
 
 - The bill prohibits "advocating" or "promoting" terrorism, although the definition of these terms is not given.
 - The Criminal Code's definition of terrorism is very permissive, including not only acts of violence, but also any act committed for a political purpose that is intended to compel any government to do or refrain from doing something [5].

# Impacts #
## Readiness #
 - Allowing CSIS to use the information it has to take action to prevent terrorist plots will reduce the response time. 

## Democracy ##
 - By lowering the standard of evidence, the new laws may lead to self-sensorship or undue surveillance of those expressing political dissent. [1]
 - The vague definitions of "advocating" and "promoting" terrorism may lead to shifting and overreaching prosecution [5].
 - It is suggested [5] that demonstrations and civil disobedience could be construed as undermining the security of Canada or its economic or financial stability.  As an example, consider demonstration by environmentalists peacefully obstructing work on a new pipeline installation [5]. 

## Culture ##
 - Material considered to be "terrorist propoganda" could be essentially removed from the Internet normally accessible to Canadians.
 - Political and artistic expression, near the fringe, may be self-sensored, since it is not clear what constitutes "terrorist propoganda". [1]
 - The uncertainty created by the law may make it more difficult for law enforcement to engage with people who are suspected to be susceptible to radicalization, because they may believe they will be found guilty for their beliefs. [5] 
 - Consider cases in other countries, in which revolutionary and violent struggle exists with a regime widely recognized to be oppressive: due to the broad definition of "terrorism" in the criminal code, vocalizing support for rebels specifically, or simply the rebellion against totalitarian regimes in principle, could be considered the advocacy of "terrorism". [5]

# In perspective #
 - In the UK in 2010 more than 65,000 pieces of unlawful terrorist related content was removed, 80% of which was jihadist groups from Iraq and Syria[1]
 - In the UK, the government reached an agreement with ISPs to voluntarily block content from outside the UK, at the request of the UK counterterrorism unit, without court order, while the law enables the government to compel hosts in the UK to remove content.[1] 
 - In Australia ISPs and websites can be compelled to remove content and action can be taken against them if they refuse.  For content outside the country, the ASIO or federal police can order ISPs or websites to block the content, without court order.[1]
 - The UK has no requirement for public disclosure about how often and what content is blocked / removed. [1]
 - Relative to France, the US, Australia, and Britain, Canada's anti-terrorism legislation is less invasive.[4]

# References #
[1] [CBC. Bill C-51 aims to 'remove terrorist propaganda' from internet](http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/bill-c-51-aims-to-remove-terrorist-propaganda-from-internet-1.2938935)  
[2] [CBC. Internet users' privacy upheld by Canada's top court](http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/internet-users-privacy-upheld-by-canada-s-top-court-1.2673823)  
[3] [Supreme Court judgment: R v. Spensor](http://scc-csc.lexum.com/scc-csc/scc-csc/en/item/14233/index.do)  
[4] [The National Post. *S.A. McCartan: Virtually all of Canada’s allies give their spy agencies powers to prevent terror. Why not us?*](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/03/s-a-mccartan-virtually-all-of-canadas-allies-give-their-spy-agencies-powers-to-prevent-terror-why-not-us/)
[5] [It’s easy to imagine Bill C-51 actually undermining Canada’s anti-terrorism strategy](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/13/national-post-view-its-easy-to-imagine-bill-c-51-actually-undermining-canadas-anti-terrorism-strategy/)
[6] [Terry Glavin: A whiff of totalitarianism in Bill C-51](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/11/terry-glavin-a-whiff-of-totalitarianism-in-bill-c-51/)

fields.title: Bill C-51 Anti-terrorism Act, 2015
fields.text:
# Background #
 - The bill allows for the sharing of information between government institutions, when such sharing is needed for said institutions to fulfill their mandates and when it is a matter of national security [7]
 - The bill establishes a list of individuals, to be maintained by the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness.  People may be added to the list if
    - the minister has reasonable grounds to suspect that they will threaten transportation security
    - commit a "terrorism offense" in Canada, or an act which, if committed in canada would constitute a "terrorism offense"
Such people may be denied travel, and Air carriers can be compelled to assist in ensuring that listed people do are unable to carry out "terrorism offenses" or acts that threaten the transportation security.
 - a listed person that has been denied transportation has the right request that their names be removed from the list, and to be given reasonable opportunity to represent themselves, as well as appeal to a judge to have their name removed.
 - with certain exceptins, the list is to be kept secret.   
 - extends the minister of transport's abilities to obtain documents from or inspect any aircraft, aerodome, or other aviation facility or any premises used by the Canadian Air Transport Security Authority.
 - the portion of the bill which has attracted particular controversy is section 83.221 (1):

    Every person who, by communicating statements, knowingly advocates or promotes the 
    commission of terrorism offences in general — other than an offence under this 
    section — while knowing that any of those offences will be committed or being 
    reckless as to whether any of those offences may be committed, as a result of such 
    communication, is guilty of an indictable offence and is liable to imprisonment for 
    a term of not more than five years. [7]

fields.title: Bill C-51 Anti-terrorism Act, 2015
fields.text:
# Background #
 - The bill allows for the sharing of information between government institutions, when such sharing is needed for said institutions to fulfill their mandates and when it is a matter of national security [7]
 - The bill establishes a list of individuals, to be maintained by the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness.  People may be added to the list if
    - the minister has reasonable grounds to suspect that they will threaten transportation security
    - commit a "terrorism offense" in Canada, or an act which, if committed in canada would constitute a "terrorism offense"
Such people may be denied travel, and Air carriers can be compelled to assist in ensuring that listed people do are unable to carry out "terrorism offenses" or acts that threaten the transportation security.
 - a listed person that has been denied transportation has the right request that their names be removed from the list, and to be given reasonable opportunity to represent themselves, as well as appeal to a judge to have their name removed.
 - with certain exceptins, the list is to be kept secret.   
 - extends the minister of transport's abilities to obtain documents from or inspect any aircraft, aerodome, or other aviation facility or any premises used by the Canadian Air Transport Security Authority.
 - the portion of the bill which has attracted particular controversy is section 83.221 (1):

> Every person who, by communicating statements, knowingly advocates or promotes the 
> commission of terrorism offences in general — other than an offence under this 
> section — while knowing that any of those offences will be committed or being  
> reckless as to whether any of those offences may be committed, as a result of such 
> communication, is guilty of an indictable offence and is liable to imprisonment for 
> a term of not more than five years. [7]

 - The RCMP runs a counter-violent extremism (CVE) program, which attempts to connect with people who hold radical views and prevent them from becoming violent.[5] 
 - Bill C-51 contains a section that gives the government the power to order Internet Service Providers (ISPs) or website administrators to remove content if a judge deems the material to be "terrorist propoganda" [1]
 - Bill C-51 targets activity that "undermines the security of Canada" by interfering with federal capabilities in relation to the country's economic or "financial stability" [6]
 - By rendering the promotion / advocacy of terrorist propoganda illegal, a valuable source of intelligence will be suppressed, driving actual terrorist plots underground. [6]
 - For comparison, existing legislation allows ordering the removal of "hate propoganda" and child pornography. [1]
 - The department of justice says that this is similar to legislation existing in UK and Australia. [1]
 - In June 2014, the Supreme Court ruled that a warrant is required for law enforcement to obtain identifying information about Canadians from ISPs. [1][2][3]
 - It is unclear how expansive "terrorrist propoganda" is.  It may be possible for artistic expression and political dissent to be construed as terrorist propoganda, interfearing with open dialogue and expression.[1] 
 - CSIS currently only has the ability to investigate, and must pass information to the RCMP who can act on it.  The bill would give CSIS the power to actively interfere with terrorist plots, by [4]:
    - cancelling travel reservations made by suspected extremists
    - blocking shipments to Canada of material that could be used in a terrorist attack
    - rendering shipments of suspected terrorist-related material unusable.
 
 - The bill prohibits "advocating" or "promoting" terrorism, although the definition of these terms is not given.
 - The Criminal Code's definition of terrorism is very permissive, including not only acts of violence, but also any act committed for a political purpose that is intended to compel any government to do or refrain from doing something [5].

# Impacts #
## Readiness #
 - Allowing CSIS to use the information it has to take action to prevent terrorist plots will reduce the response time. 

## Democracy ##
 - By lowering the standard of evidence, the new laws may lead to self-sensorship or undue surveillance of those expressing political dissent. [1]
 - The vague definitions of "advocating" and "promoting" terrorism may lead to shifting and overreaching prosecution [5].
 - It is suggested [6] that demonstrations and civil disobedience could be construed as undermining the security of Canada or its economic or financial stability.  As an example, consider demonstration by environmentalists peacefully obstructing work on a new pipeline installation [6]. 

## Culture ##
 - Material considered to be "terrorist propoganda" could be essentially removed from the Internet normally accessible to Canadians.
 - Political and artistic expression, near the fringe, may be self-sensored, since it is not clear what constitutes "terrorist propoganda". [1]
 - The uncertainty created by the law may make it more difficult for law enforcement to engage with people who are suspected to be susceptible to radicalization, because they may believe they will be found guilty for their beliefs. [5] 
 - Consider cases in other countries, in which revolutionary and violent struggle exists with a regime widely recognized to be oppressive: due to the broad definition of "terrorism" in the criminal code, vocalizing support for rebels specifically, or simply the rebellion against totalitarian regimes in principle, could be considered the advocacy of "terrorism". [6]

# In perspective #
 - In the UK in 2010 more than 65,000 pieces of unlawful terrorist related content was removed, 80% of which was jihadist groups from Iraq and Syria[1]
 - In the UK, the government reached an agreement with ISPs to voluntarily block content from outside the UK, at the request of the UK counterterrorism unit, without court order, while the law enables the government to compel hosts in the UK to remove content.[1] 
 - In Australia ISPs and websites can be compelled to remove content and action can be taken against them if they refuse.  For content outside the country, the ASIO or federal police can order ISPs or websites to block the content, without court order.[1]
 - The UK has no requirement for public disclosure about how often and what content is blocked / removed. [1]
 - Relative to France, the US, Australia, and Britain, Canada's anti-terrorism legislation is less invasive.[4]

# References #
[1] [CBC. Bill C-51 aims to 'remove terrorist propaganda' from internet](http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/bill-c-51-aims-to-remove-terrorist-propaganda-from-internet-1.2938935)  
[2] [CBC. Internet users' privacy upheld by Canada's top court](http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/internet-users-privacy-upheld-by-canada-s-top-court-1.2673823)  
[3] [Supreme Court judgment: R v. Spensor](http://scc-csc.lexum.com/scc-csc/scc-csc/en/item/14233/index.do)  
[4] [The National Post. *S.A. McCartan: Virtually all of Canada’s allies give their spy agencies powers to prevent terror. Why not us?*](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/03/s-a-mccartan-virtually-all-of-canadas-allies-give-their-spy-agencies-powers-to-prevent-terror-why-not-us/)  
[5] [It’s easy to imagine Bill C-51 actually undermining Canada’s anti-terrorism strategy](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/13/national-post-view-its-easy-to-imagine-bill-c-51-actually-undermining-canadas-anti-terrorism-strategy/)  
[6] [Terry Glavin: A whiff of totalitarianism in Bill C-51](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/11/terry-glavin-a-whiff-of-totalitarianism-in-bill-c-51/)  
[7] [Bill C-51, Anti-terrorism Act, 2015](http://www.parl.gc.ca/HousePublications/Publication.aspx?Language=E&Mode=1&DocId=6932136&File=32#1)

[3] [Supreme Court judgment: R v. Spensor](http://scc-csc.lexum.com/scc-csc/scc-csc/en/item/14233/index.do)  
[4] [The National Post. *S.A. McCartan: Virtually all of Canada’s allies give their spy agencies powers to prevent terror. Why not us?*](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/03/s-a-mccartan-virtually-all-of-canadas-allies-give-their-spy-agencies-powers-to-prevent-terror-why-not-us/)  
[5] [It’s easy to imagine Bill C-51 actually undermining Canada’s anti-terrorism strategy](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/13/national-post-view-its-easy-to-imagine-bill-c-51-actually-undermining-canadas-anti-terrorism-strategy/)  
[6] [Terry Glavin: A whiff of totalitarianism in Bill C-51](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/11/terry-glavin-a-whiff-of-totalitarianism-in-bill-c-51/)

fields.summary: Bill C-51 provides new powers to CSIS to counter terrorism by pre-emptively interfearing with the transfer of funds or the delivery of materials.  It introduces the power for the government, with judicial approval, to compel Internet Service Providers (ISPs) or websites to remove terrorist material.

fields.title: Bill C-51 Anti-terrorism Act, 2015
fields.text:
# Background #
 - The bill allows for the sharing of information between government institutions, when such sharing is needed for said institutions to fulfill their mandates and when it is a matter of national security [7]
 - 
 - The bill establishes a list of individuals, to be maintained by the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness.  People may be added to the list if
    - the minister has reasonable grounds to suspect that they will threaten transportation security
    - commit a "terrorism offense" in Canada, or an act which, if committed in canada would constitute a "terrorism offense"
Such people may be denied travel, and Air carriers can be compelled to assist in ensuring that listed people do are unable to carry out "terrorism offenses" or acts that threaten the transportation security.
 - a listed person that has been denied transportation has the right request that their names be removed from the list, and to be given reasonable opportunity to represent themselves, as well as appeal to a judge to have their name removed.
 - with certain exceptins, the list is to be kept secret.   
 - extends the minister of transport's abilities to obtain documents from or inspect any aircraft, aerodome, or other aviation facility or any premises used by the Canadian Air Transport Security Authority.
 - the portion of the bill which has attracted particular controversy is section 83.221 (1):

     *Every person who, by communicating statements, knowingly advocates or promotes 
     the commission of terrorism offences in general — other than an offence under this 
     section — while knowing that any of those offences will be committed or being 
     reckless as to whether any of those offences may be committed, as a result of such 
     communication, is guilty of an indictable offence and is liable to imprisonment 
     for a term of not more than five years.* [7]

 - The RCMP runs a counter-violent extremism (CVE) program, which attempts to connect with people who hold radical views and prevent them from becoming violent.[5] 
 - Bill C-51 contains a section that gives the government the power to order Internet Service Providers (ISPs) or website administrators to remove content if a judge deems the material to be "terrorist propoganda" [1]
 - Bill C-51 targets activity that "undermines the security of Canada" by interfering with federal capabilities in relation to the country's economic or "financial stability" [6]
 - By rendering the promotion / advocacy of terrorist propoganda illegal, a valuable source of intelligence will be suppressed, driving actual terrorist plots underground. [6]
 - For comparison, existing legislation allows ordering the removal of "hate propoganda" and child pornography. [1]
 - The department of justice says that this is similar to legislation existing in UK and Australia. [1]
 - In the bill, terrorist propoganda is defined as 

 	
    “terrorist propaganda” means any writing, sign, visible 
    representation or audio recording that advocates or promotes the 
    commission of terrorism offences in general — other than an offence 
    under subsection 83.221(1) — or counsels the commission of a 
    terrorism offence. [7]

 - The bill allows judges to order "custodians" of computer systems (such as the operators of websites, or ISPs) to delete material deemed to be terrorist propoganda.  The originator of the material can appear before the judge to represent themselves and appeal the decision.[7]
 - The bill allows for the detainment, without warrant, of a person who "may" commit a terrorist act, for a limited period of time (about 24 hours) if it is not practical to obtain a warrant first.[7]
 - In June 2014, the Supreme Court ruled that a warrant is required for law enforcement to obtain identifying information about Canadians from ISPs. [1][2][3]
 - It is unclear how expansive "terrorrist propoganda" is.  It may be possible for artistic expression and political dissent to be construed as terrorist propoganda, interfearing with open dialogue and expression.[1] 
 - CSIS currently only has the ability to investigate, and must pass information to the RCMP who can act on it.  The bill would give CSIS the power to actively interfere with terrorist plots, by [4]:
    - cancelling travel reservations made by suspected extremists
    - blocking shipments to Canada of material that could be used in a terrorist attack
    - rendering shipments of suspected terrorist-related material unusable.
 
 - The bill prohibits "advocating" or "promoting" terrorism, although the definition of these terms is not given.
 - The Criminal Code's definition of terrorism is very permissive, including not only acts of violence, but also any act committed for a political purpose that is intended to compel any government to do or refrain from doing something [5].

# Impacts #
## Readiness #
 - Allowing CSIS to use the information it has to take action to prevent terrorist plots will reduce the response time. 

## Democracy ##
 - By lowering the standard of evidence, the new laws may lead to self-sensorship or undue surveillance of those expressing political dissent. [1]
 - The vague definitions of "advocating" and "promoting" terrorism may lead to shifting and overreaching prosecution [5].
 - It is suggested [6] that demonstrations and civil disobedience could be construed as undermining the security of Canada or its economic or financial stability.  As an example, consider demonstration by environmentalists peacefully obstructing work on a new pipeline installation [6]. 

## Culture ##
 - Material considered to be "terrorist propoganda" could be essentially removed from the Internet normally accessible to Canadians.
 - Political and artistic expression, near the fringe, may be self-sensored, since it is not clear what constitutes "terrorist propoganda". [1]
 - The uncertainty created by the law may make it more difficult for law enforcement to engage with people who are suspected to be susceptible to radicalization, because they may believe they will be found guilty for their beliefs. [5] 
 - Consider cases in other countries, in which revolutionary and violent struggle exists with a regime widely recognized to be oppressive: due to the broad definition of "terrorism" in the criminal code, vocalizing support for rebels specifically, or simply the rebellion against totalitarian regimes in principle, could be considered the advocacy of "terrorism". [6]

# In perspective #
 - In the UK in 2010 more than 65,000 pieces of unlawful terrorist related content was removed, 80% of which was jihadist groups from Iraq and Syria[1]
 - In the UK, the government reached an agreement with ISPs to voluntarily block content from outside the UK, at the request of the UK counterterrorism unit, without court order, while the law enables the government to compel hosts in the UK to remove content.[1] 
 - In Australia ISPs and websites can be compelled to remove content and action can be taken against them if they refuse.  For content outside the country, the ASIO or federal police can order ISPs or websites to block the content, without court order.[1]
 - The UK has no requirement for public disclosure about how often and what content is blocked / removed. [1]
 - Relative to France, the US, Australia, and Britain, Canada's anti-terrorism legislation is less invasive.[4]

# References #
[1] [CBC. Bill C-51 aims to 'remove terrorist propaganda' from internet](http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/bill-c-51-aims-to-remove-terrorist-propaganda-from-internet-1.2938935)  
[2] [CBC. Internet users' privacy upheld by Canada's top court](http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/internet-users-privacy-upheld-by-canada-s-top-court-1.2673823)  
[3] [Supreme Court judgment: R v. Spensor](http://scc-csc.lexum.com/scc-csc/scc-csc/en/item/14233/index.do)  
[4] [The National Post. *S.A. McCartan: Virtually all of Canada’s allies give their spy agencies powers to prevent terror. Why not us?*](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/03/s-a-mccartan-virtually-all-of-canadas-allies-give-their-spy-agencies-powers-to-prevent-terror-why-not-us/)  
[5] [It’s easy to imagine Bill C-51 actually undermining Canada’s anti-terrorism strategy](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/13/national-post-view-its-easy-to-imagine-bill-c-51-actually-undermining-canadas-anti-terrorism-strategy/)  
[6] [Terry Glavin: A whiff of totalitarianism in Bill C-51](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/11/terry-glavin-a-whiff-of-totalitarianism-in-bill-c-51/)  
[7] [Bill C-51, Anti-terrorism Act, 2015](http://www.parl.gc.ca/HousePublications/Publication.aspx?Language=E&Mode=1&DocId=6932136&File=32#1)
