fields.summary: The anti-terrorism act introduces several measures aimed at countering terrorism.  It expands CSIS's powers, permitting CSIS not only to investigate, but to actively disrupt terrorist activities.  The bill allows for the sharing of personally identifying information about Canadians, between government institutions, when it is a matter of national security.  The Bill reduces the standard of evidence for taking enforcement action against terrorist offenses that are believed will occur.  It renders the "promotion" or "advocacy" of terrorist offenses illegal.

fields.title: Bill C-51 Anti-terrorism Act, 2015
fields.text:
# Background #

## "Terrorism offense" and "Terrorist propoganda" ##
It is important to understand the meaning of "terrorism offenses", and other related ideas.  Many concerns about the bill have been raised due to the notion of terrorism being too broad. The definition of "terrorism" in the Criminal Code includes not only acts of violence, but also any act committed for a political purpose that is intended to compel any government to do or refrain from doing something [5].

Terrorist propoganda, in turn, is defined in Bill C-51 as "advocating" or "promoting" a terrorism offense [7].  From the bill:

     “terrorist propaganda” means any writing, sign, visible 
     representation or audio recording that advocates or promotes the 
     commission of terrorism offences in general — other than an offence 
     under subsection 83.221(1) — or counsels the commission of a 
     terrorism offence. [7] 

It is, therefore, unclear how expansive "terrorrist propoganda" is [1].  Bill C-51 also introduces the notion of actions that "undermin[e] the security of Canada or its economic or financial stability", which might be interpreted broadly [6][7]


## Lower threshold for evidence ##
In various other places, with respect to legislature relating to terrorist activities, the standard of evidence has been reduced from a reasonable belief that acts will be committed, to a resonable belief that acts *may* be committed [7].  The bill allows for the detainment, without warrant, of a person who "may" commit a terrorist act, for a limited period of time if it is not practical to obtain a warrant first.  This period has been extended from three to seven days [].  



## Criminalization of terrorist propoganda ##
The act introduces new laws prohibiting the "advocacy" or "promation" of terrorism offenses.  Section 83.221(1) appears to have drawn the most concern from critics:

     *Every person who, by communicating statements, knowingly advocates or promotes 
     the commission of terrorism offences in general — other than an offence under this 
     section — while knowing that any of those offences will be committed or being 
     reckless as to whether any of those offences may be committed, as a result of such 
     communication, is guilty of an indictable offence and is liable to imprisonment 
     for a term of not more than five years.* [7]


 - In the bill, terrorist propoganda is defined as 




## Removal of terrorist propoganda ##
 - The bill allows judges to order "custodians" of computer systems (such as the operators of websites, or ISPs) to delete material deemed to be terrorist propoganda.  The originator of the material can appear before the judge to represent themselves and appeal the decision.[7]
 - Bill C-51 contains a section that gives the government the power to order Internet Service Providers (ISPs) or website administrators to remove content if a judge deems the material to be "terrorist propoganda" [1]
 - The RCMP runs a counter-violent extremism (CVE) program, which attempts to connect with people who hold radical views and prevent them from becoming violent.[5] 
 - For comparison, existing legislation allows ordering the removal of "hate propoganda" and child pornography. [1]
 - The department of justice says that this is similar to legislation existing in UK and Australia. [1]


## New Powers for CSIS ##
 - CSIS currently only has the ability to investigate, and must pass information to the RCMP who can act on it.  The bill would give CSIS the power to actively interfere with terrorist plots, by [4]:
    - cancelling travel reservations made by suspected extremists
    - blocking shipments to Canada of material that could be used in a terrorist attack
    - rendering shipments of suspected terrorist-related material unusable.




## Privacy ##
 - The bill allows for the sharing of information between government institutions, when such sharing is needed for said institutions to fulfill their mandates and when it is a matter of national security [7]
 - In June 2014, the Supreme Court ruled that a warrant is required for law enforcement to obtain identifying information about Canadians from ISPs. [1][2][3]
 - Judges can order ISPs to provide identidying information of the sources of terrorist propoganda so that they may be located [4]






## No fly list ##
 - The bill establishes a list of individuals, to be maintained by the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness.  People may be added to the list if
    - the minister has reasonable grounds to suspect that they will threaten transportation security
    - commit a "terrorism offense" in Canada, or an act which, if committed in canada would constitute a "terrorism offense"
Such people may be denied travel, and Air carriers can be compelled to assist in ensuring that listed people do are unable to carry out "terrorism offenses" or acts that threaten the transportation security.
 - a listed person that has been denied transportation has the right request that their names be removed from the list, and to be given reasonable opportunity to represent themselves, as well as appeal to a judge to have their name removed.
 - with certain exceptins, the list is to be kept secret.   

 - extends the minister of transport's abilities to obtain documents from or inspect any aircraft, aerodome, or other aviation facility or any premises used by the Canadian Air Transport Security Authority.






# Impacts #
## Readiness #
 - Allowing CSIS to use the information it has to take action to prevent terrorist plots will reduce the response time. 
 - By rendering the promotion / advocacy of terrorist propoganda illegal, a valuable source of intelligence will be suppressed, driving actual terrorist plots underground. [6]


## Democracy ##
 - By lowering the standard of evidence, the new laws may lead to self-sensorship or undue surveillance of those expressing political dissent. [1]
 - The vague definitions of "advocating" and "promoting" terrorism may lead to shifting and overreaching prosecution [5].
 - It is suggested [6] that demonstrations and civil disobedience could be construed as undermining the security of Canada or its economic or financial stability.  As an example, consider demonstration by environmentalists peacefully obstructing work on a new pipeline installation [6]. 

## Culture ##
 - Material considered to be "terrorist propoganda" could be essentially removed from the Internet normally accessible to Canadians.
 - Political and artistic expression, near the fringe, may be self-sensored, since it is not clear what constitutes "terrorist propoganda". [1]
 - The uncertainty created by the law may make it more difficult for law enforcement to engage with people who are suspected to be susceptible to radicalization, because they may believe they will be found guilty for their beliefs. [5] 
 - Consider cases in other countries, in which revolutionary and violent struggle exists with a regime widely recognized to be oppressive: due to the broad definition of "terrorism" in the criminal code, vocalizing support for rebels specifically, or simply the rebellion against totalitarian regimes in principle, could be considered the advocacy of "terrorism". [6]
It may be possible for artistic expression and political dissent to be construed as terrorist propoganda, interfearing with open dialogue and expression.[1] 


# In perspective #
 - In the UK in 2010 more than 65,000 pieces of unlawful terrorist related content was removed, 80% of which was jihadist groups from Iraq and Syria[1]
 - In the UK, the government reached an agreement with ISPs to voluntarily block content from outside the UK, at the request of the UK counterterrorism unit, without court order, while the law enables the government to compel hosts in the UK to remove content.[1] 
 - In Australia ISPs and websites can be compelled to remove content and action can be taken against them if they refuse.  For content outside the country, the ASIO or federal police can order ISPs or websites to block the content, without court order.[1]
 - The UK has no requirement for public disclosure about how often and what content is blocked / removed. [1]
 - Relative to France, the US, Australia, and Britain, Canada's anti-terrorism legislation is less invasive.[4]

# References #
[1] [CBC. Bill C-51 aims to 'remove terrorist propaganda' from internet](http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/bill-c-51-aims-to-remove-terrorist-propaganda-from-internet-1.2938935)  
[2] [CBC. Internet users' privacy upheld by Canada's top court](http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/internet-users-privacy-upheld-by-canada-s-top-court-1.2673823)  
[3] [Supreme Court judgment: R v. Spensor](http://scc-csc.lexum.com/scc-csc/scc-csc/en/item/14233/index.do)  
[4] [The National Post. *S.A. McCartan: Virtually all of Canada’s allies give their spy agencies powers to prevent terror. Why not us?*](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/03/s-a-mccartan-virtually-all-of-canadas-allies-give-their-spy-agencies-powers-to-prevent-terror-why-not-us/)  
[5] [It’s easy to imagine Bill C-51 actually undermining Canada’s anti-terrorism strategy](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/13/national-post-view-its-easy-to-imagine-bill-c-51-actually-undermining-canadas-anti-terrorism-strategy/)  
[6] [Terry Glavin: A whiff of totalitarianism in Bill C-51](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/11/terry-glavin-a-whiff-of-totalitarianism-in-bill-c-51/)  
[7] [Bill C-51, Anti-terrorism Act, 2015](http://www.parl.gc.ca/HousePublications/Publication.aspx?Language=E&Mode=1&DocId=6932136&File=32#1)  
[8] [Anti-terrorism powers: What's in the legislation?](http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/anti-terrorism-powers-what-s-in-the-legislation-1.2937964)

## Removal of terrorist propoganda ##
The bill also enables judges to order the deletion material deemed to be terrorist propoganda from computer systems [1][7].  The originator of the material can appear before the judge to represent themselves and appeal the decision.[7]
Currently, the RCMP runs a counter-violent extremism (CVE) program, which attempts to connect with people who hold radical views and prevent them from becoming violent [5], and it the criminalization of terrorist propoganda might interfere with the availability of natural intelligence through social media. 


## New Powers for CSIS ##
CSIS currently only has the ability to investigate, and must pass information to the RCMP who can act on it.  The bill would give CSIS the power to actively interfere in order to prevent terrorism offenses, by taking certain actions, including [4]:
    - cancelling travel reservations made by suspected extremists
    - blocking shipments to Canada of material that could be used in a terrorist attack
    - rendering shipments of suspected terrorist-related material unusable.




## Privacy ##
The bill allows for the sharing of information between government institutions, when such sharing is needed for said institutions to fulfill their mandates and when it is a matter of national security [7].  Judges can order ISPs to provide identidying information of the sources of terrorist propoganda so that they may be located [4].  Recall that in June 2014, the Supreme Court ruled that a warrant is required for law enforcement to obtain identifying information about Canadians from ISPs [1][2][3].



## No fly list ##
The so-called "no fly list" is a secret list of individuals that may be prevented from traveling, or subject to screening, by the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness.  Airline carriers are legally required to cooperate in this respect.

The bill lowers the threshold for evidence needed to put people onto the "no fly list" and establishes the appeal process for individuals who have been prevented from traveling [7][8]





# Impacts #
## Readiness #
 - Allowing CSIS to use the information it has to take action to prevent terrorist plots will reduce the response time. 
 - By rendering the promotion / advocacy of terrorist propoganda illegal, a valuable source of intelligence will be suppressed, driving actual terrorist plots underground. [6]


## Democracy ##
 - By lowering the standard of evidence, the new laws may lead to self-sensorship or undue surveillance of those expressing political dissent. [1]
 - The vague definitions of "advocating" and "promoting" terrorism may lead to shifting and overreaching prosecution [5].
 - It is suggested [6] that demonstrations and civil disobedience could be construed as undermining the security of Canada or its economic or financial stability.  As an example, consider demonstration by environmentalists peacefully obstructing work on a new pipeline installation [6]. 

## Culture ##
 - Material considered to be "terrorist propoganda" could be essentially removed from the Internet normally accessible to Canadians.
 - Political and artistic expression, near the fringe, may be self-sensored, since it is not clear what constitutes "terrorist propoganda". [1]
 - The uncertainty created by the law may make it more difficult for law enforcement to engage with people who are suspected to be susceptible to radicalization, because they may believe they will be found guilty for their beliefs. [5] 
 - Consider cases in other countries, in which revolutionary and violent struggle exists with a regime widely recognized to be oppressive: due to the broad definition of "terrorism" in the criminal code, vocalizing support for rebels specifically, or simply the rebellion against totalitarian regimes in principle, could be considered the advocacy of "terrorism". [6]
It may be possible for artistic expression and political dissent to be construed as terrorist propoganda, interfearing with open dialogue and expression.[1] 


# In perspective #
 - Existing legislation allows a judge to order the removal of "hate propoganda" and child pornography [1]
 - In the UK in 2010 more than 65,000 pieces of unlawful terrorist related content was removed, 80% of which was jihadist groups from Iraq and Syria [1]
 - The UK has no requirement for public disclosure about how often and what content is blocked / removed. [1]
 - In the UK, the government reached an agreement with ISPs to voluntarily block content from outside the UK, at the request of the UK counterterrorism unit, without court order [1] 
 - In Australia ISPs and websites can be compelled to remove content and action can be taken against them if they refuse.  For content outside the country, the ASIO or federal police can order ISPs or websites to block the content, without court order.[1]
 - Relative to France, the US, Australia, and Britain, Canada's anti-terrorism legislation is "less invasive".[4]

# References #
[1] [CBC. Bill C-51 aims to 'remove terrorist propaganda' from internet](http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/bill-c-51-aims-to-remove-terrorist-propaganda-from-internet-1.2938935)  
[2] [CBC. Internet users' privacy upheld by Canada's top court](http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/internet-users-privacy-upheld-by-canada-s-top-court-1.2673823)  
[3] [Supreme Court judgment: R v. Spensor](http://scc-csc.lexum.com/scc-csc/scc-csc/en/item/14233/index.do)  
[4] [The National Post. *S.A. McCartan: Virtually all of Canada’s allies give their spy agencies powers to prevent terror. Why not us?*](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/03/s-a-mccartan-virtually-all-of-canadas-allies-give-their-spy-agencies-powers-to-prevent-terror-why-not-us/)  
[5] [It’s easy to imagine Bill C-51 actually undermining Canada’s anti-terrorism strategy](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/13/national-post-view-its-easy-to-imagine-bill-c-51-actually-undermining-canadas-anti-terrorism-strategy/)  
[6] [Terry Glavin: A whiff of totalitarianism in Bill C-51](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/11/terry-glavin-a-whiff-of-totalitarianism-in-bill-c-51/)  
[7] [Bill C-51, Anti-terrorism Act, 2015](http://www.parl.gc.ca/HousePublications/Publication.aspx?Language=E&Mode=1&DocId=6932136&File=32#1)  
[8] [Anti-terrorism powers: What's in the legislation?](http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/anti-terrorism-powers-what-s-in-the-legislation-1.2937964)
fields.summary: The anti-terrorism act introduces several measures aimed at countering terrorism.  It expands CSIS's powers, permitting CSIS not only to investigate, but to actively disrupt terrorist activities.  The bill allows for the sharing of personally identifying information about Canadians, between government institutions, when it is a matter of national security.  The Bill reduces the standard of evidence for taking enforcement action against terrorist offenses that are believed will occur.  It renders the "promotion" or "advocacy" of terrorist offenses illegal.

fields.title: Bill C-51 Anti-terrorism Act, 2015
fields.text:
# Background #

## "Terrorism offense" and "Terrorist propoganda" ##
It is important to understand the meaning of "terrorism offenses", and other related ideas.  Many concerns about the bill have been raised due to the notion of terrorism being too broad. The definition of "terrorism" in the Criminal Code includes not only acts of violence, but also any act committed for a political purpose that is intended to compel any government to do or refrain from doing something [5].

Terrorist propoganda, in turn, is defined in Bill C-51 as "advocating" or "promoting" a terrorism offense [7].  From the bill:

     “terrorist propaganda” means any writing, sign, visible 
     representation or audio recording that advocates or promotes the 
     commission of terrorism offences in general — other than an offence 
     under subsection 83.221(1) — or counsels the commission of a 
     terrorism offence. [7] 

It is, therefore, unclear how expansive "terrorrist propoganda" is [1].  Bill C-51 also introduces the notion of actions that "undermin[e] the security of Canada or its economic or financial stability", which might be interpreted broadly [6][7]


## Lower threshold for evidence ##
In various other places, with respect to legislature relating to terrorist activities, the standard of evidence has been reduced from a reasonable belief that acts will be committed, to a resonable belief that acts *may* be committed [7].  The bill allows for the detainment, without warrant, of a person who "may" commit a terrorist act, for a limited period of time if it is not practical to obtain a warrant first.  This period has been extended from three to seven days [].  



## Criminalization of terrorist propoganda ##
The bill introduces new laws prohibiting the "advocacy" or "promation" of terrorism offenses.  Section 83.221(1) appears to have drawn the most concern from critics:

     Every person who, by communicating statements, knowingly advocates or promotes 
     the commission of terrorism offences in general — other than an offence under this 
     section — while knowing that any of those offences will be committed or being 
     reckless as to whether any of those offences may be committed, as a result of such 
     communication, is guilty of an indictable offence and is liable to imprisonment 
     for a term of not more than five years. [7]




## Removal of terrorist propoganda ##
The bill also enables judges to order the deletion material deemed to be terrorist propoganda from computer systems [1][7].  The originator of the material can appear before the judge to represent themselves and appeal the decision.[7]
Currently, the RCMP runs a counter-violent extremism (CVE) program, which attempts to connect with people who hold radical views and prevent them from becoming violent [5], and it the criminalization of terrorist propoganda might interfere with the availability of natural intelligence through social media. 




## New Powers for CSIS ##
CSIS currently only has the ability to investigate, and must pass information to the RCMP who can act on it.  The bill would give CSIS the power to actively interfere in order to prevent terrorism offenses, by taking certain actions, including [4]:
    - cancelling travel reservations made by suspected extremists
    - blocking shipments to Canada of material that could be used in a terrorist attack
    - rendering shipments of suspected terrorist-related material unusable.




## Privacy ##
The bill allows for the sharing of information between government institutions, when such sharing is needed for said institutions to fulfill their mandates and when it is a matter of national security [7].  Judges can order ISPs to provide identidying information of the sources of terrorist propoganda so that they may be located [4].  Recall that in June 2014, the Supreme Court ruled that a warrant is required for law enforcement to obtain identifying information about Canadians from ISPs [1][2][3].



## No fly list ##
The so-called "no fly list" is a secret list of individuals that may be prevented from traveling, or subject to screening, by the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness.  Airline carriers are legally required to cooperate in this respect.

The bill lowers the threshold for evidence needed to put people onto the "no fly list" and establishes the appeal process for individuals who have been prevented from traveling [7][8]





# Impacts #
## Readiness #
Allowing CSIS to use the information it has to take action to prevent terrorist plots will reduce the response time, and will likely lead to more effective protection against terrorist activities [4].

By rendering the promotion / advocacy of terrorist propoganda illegal, a valuable source of intelligence will be suppressed, driving actual terrorist plots underground. [6]


## Democracy ##
By lowering the standard of evidence, the new laws may lead to self-sensorship or undue surveillance of those expressing political dissent [1].  The vague definitions of "advocating" and "promoting" terrorism may lead to "prosecutory overreach" [5].

It has been suggested [6] that protests and civil disobedience could be construed as undermining the security of Canada or its economic or financial stability.  As an example, consider demonstration by environmentalists peacefully obstructing work on a new pipeline installation [6]. 


## Culture ##
Material considered to be "terrorist propoganda" could be partially removed from the Internet normally accessible to Canadians.
Political and artistic expression, "near the fringe", may be self-censored, since it is not clear what constitutes "terrorist propaganda". [1]

The uncertainty created by the law may make it more difficult for law enforcement to engage with people who are suspected to be susceptible to radicalization, for example, as part of the CVE program, because those people might be more fearful of law enforcement [5]. 

The wide interpretation of "terrorism advocacy" could hamper the freedom of expression.  Consider cases in other countries, in which revolutionary and violent struggle exists with a regime widely recognized to be oppressive: due to the broad definition of "terrorism" in the criminal code, vocalizing support for rebels could be considered the advocacy of "terrorism" [6].



# In perspective #
 - Existing legislation allows a judge to order the removal of "hate propoganda" and child pornography [1]
 - In the UK in 2010 more than 65,000 pieces of unlawful terrorist related content was removed, 80% of which was jihadist groups from Iraq and Syria [1]
 - The UK has no requirement for public disclosure about how often and what content is blocked / removed. [1]
 - In the UK, the government reached an agreement with ISPs to voluntarily block content from outside the UK, at the request of the UK counterterrorism unit, without court order [1] 
 - In Australia ISPs and websites can be compelled to remove content and action can be taken against them if they refuse.  For content outside the country, the ASIO or federal police can order ISPs or websites to block the content, without court order.[1]
 - Relative to France, the US, Australia, and Britain, Canada's anti-terrorism legislation is "less invasive".[4]

# References #
[1] [CBC. Bill C-51 aims to 'remove terrorist propaganda' from internet](http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/bill-c-51-aims-to-remove-terrorist-propaganda-from-internet-1.2938935)  
[2] [CBC. Internet users' privacy upheld by Canada's top court](http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/internet-users-privacy-upheld-by-canada-s-top-court-1.2673823)  
[3] [Supreme Court judgment: R v. Spensor](http://scc-csc.lexum.com/scc-csc/scc-csc/en/item/14233/index.do)  
[4] [The National Post. *S.A. McCartan: Virtually all of Canada’s allies give their spy agencies powers to prevent terror. Why not us?*](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/03/s-a-mccartan-virtually-all-of-canadas-allies-give-their-spy-agencies-powers-to-prevent-terror-why-not-us/)  
[5] [It’s easy to imagine Bill C-51 actually undermining Canada’s anti-terrorism strategy](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/13/national-post-view-its-easy-to-imagine-bill-c-51-actually-undermining-canadas-anti-terrorism-strategy/)  
[6] [Terry Glavin: A whiff of totalitarianism in Bill C-51](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/11/terry-glavin-a-whiff-of-totalitarianism-in-bill-c-51/)  
[7] [Bill C-51, Anti-terrorism Act, 2015](http://www.parl.gc.ca/HousePublications/Publication.aspx?Language=E&Mode=1&DocId=6932136&File=32#1)  
[8] [Anti-terrorism powers: What's in the legislation?](http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/anti-terrorism-powers-what-s-in-the-legislation-1.2937964)

 - Relative to France, the USA, Australia, and the UK, Canada's anti-terrorism legislation is "less invasive" [4].

[1] [CBC. Bill C-51 aims to 'remove terrorist propaganda' from Internet](http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/bill-c-51-aims-to-remove-terrorist-propaganda-from-internet-1.2938935)  
[2] [CBC. Internet users' privacy upheld by Canada's top court](http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/internet-users-privacy-upheld-by-canada-s-top-court-1.2673823)  
[3] [Supreme Court judgment: R v. Spensor](http://scc-csc.lexum.com/scc-csc/scc-csc/en/item/14233/index.do)  
[4] [The National Post. *S.A. McCartan: Virtually all of Canada’s allies give their spy agencies powers to prevent terror. Why not us?*](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/03/s-a-mccartan-virtually-all-of-canadas-allies-give-their-spy-agencies-powers-to-prevent-terror-why-not-us/)  
[5] [It’s easy to imagine Bill C-51 actually undermining Canada’s anti-terrorism strategy](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/13/national-post-view-its-easy-to-imagine-bill-c-51-actually-undermining-canadas-anti-terrorism-strategy/)  
[6] [Terry Glavin: A whiff of totalitarianism in Bill C-51](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/11/terry-glavin-a-whiff-of-totalitarianism-in-bill-c-51/)  
[7] [Bill C-51, Anti-terrorism Act, 2015](http://www.parl.gc.ca/HousePublications/Publication.aspx?Language=E&Mode=1&DocId=6932136&File=32#1)  
[8] [Anti-terrorism powers: What's in the legislation?](http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/anti-terrorism-powers-what-s-in-the-legislation-1.2937964)
fields.summary: The anti-terrorism act introduces several measures aimed at countering terrorism.  It expands CSIS's powers, permitting CSIS not only to investigate, but to actively disrupt terrorist activities.  Bill C-51 allows for the sharing of personally identifying information about Canadians, between government institutions, when it is a matter of national security.  Bill C-51 reduces the standard of evidence for taking enforcement action against terrorist offences that are believed will occur.  It renders the "promotion" or "advocacy" of terrorist offences illegal.

fields.title: Doubling TFSA contribution limits
fields.text:
#Background#
The TFSA account was first introduced in 2009 to encourage Canadians to save. Originally the account allowed for contributions of up to $5,000 per year. 

# Actors #
 - **Government**: The Government wants to provide incentive for Canadians to save money. At the same time it has to balance the budget and ensure that no group of Canadians are unfairly benefiting from the regulations. 
 - **Banks**: Banks benefit by holding TFSA deposits because the rules of this account discourage Canadians from withdrawing money on a regular basis. When money is withdrawn from a TFSA account, the contribution room is not freed up until the following year. By having longer-term accounts banks can invest the funds in lucrative mortgages or credit card offers, while giving only a negligible portion of the earnings as interest back to the TFSA account holder.
 - **Average Canadians**: The average working class Canadian benefits from TFSA accounts by means of tax-free interest and incentive to keep healthy financial discipline.
 - **Savvy investors and traders**: Savvy investors and traders are able to exploit the full potential of a TFSA. The TFSA is a very flexible investment vehicle, particularly if used as a self-directed account. It can hold a large variety of securities and financial instruments, similar to a RRSP account. The few exclusions relate to shares in companies of which the TFSA account holder has controlling role. Savvy individuals with access to highly lucrative investments have a virtually unlimited potential to earn tax-free income by re-investing earnings within the TFSA account.

# Impacts #
## Unfair advantages ##
**Tax avoidance**. When the TFSA was first introduced, savvy investors and traders took unfair advantage of the weak penalties for over-contribution and unqualified investments. The original penalty for over contribution was only 1% per month (and only on the over-contributions). Wealthy investors with access to investments with high returns were over-contributing $100,000 or more, paying the 1% penalty and still keeping all returns as tax-free income. Furthermore, initially the penalty for purchasing prohibited investments inside a TFSA (such as the shares of a company you control) was simply forfeiting the purchase. I.e., investors with questionable morality were allowed to keep any capital gains from breaking the rules, without paying tax[1].
While the rules have since changed to prevent the most obvious tax avoidance schemes, questions still remain about what other opportunities for abuse are being exploited.

**Unequal opportunities**. In 2010 big banks held 75% of Tax-Free Savings Accounts[2]. That is to say, 75% of accounts were giving their owners only the marginal interest rate that the big banks offer. At the same time, the remaining 25% of TFSAs were self-directed or held by other institutions, offering lucrative investments with limitless tax exemption to those in the know. Fast-forward to 2012, less than 16% of TFSA account holders under 60 years old had reached the $5,500 contribution limit[3]. I.e., only 16% of the economically active Canadian residents with TFSA accounts have enough spare income to reach the $5,500 TFSA contribution limit. If the limit is doubled, then, fewer than 16% of working Canadians will be able to benefit from this tax-break.

## Economic Impacts ##
**Loss of tax income**. By having no limits on the types of investments in a TFSA, the government in power leaves an unpredictable tax loss for future governments. The amount of tax wealthy investors and knowledgeable traders will not pay into future budgets depends only on their luck and skills. Doubling the contribution limit has cumulative impact on the tax loss, as any earnings can be re-invested freely.

**Reduced economic activity**. Encouraging Canadians to invest up to $11,000 of their yearly income in a savings account and penalizing them (by means of lost contribution room) for withdrawals, may negatively impact local businesses as less money will be circulating in the economy. This will put deflationary pressure on an economy that is already struggling to achieve inflation targets.

**Cushion for rate hike**. The TFSA can have a positive impact on the economy by providing a cushion for future changes that may take households by surprise. For instance, the abnormally low interest rate has allowed a large number of people to take mortgages. If the interest rates recover, a TFSA could save home-owners who are facing unexpected increase in the payments for their home.

# References #
[1] http://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/personal-finance/tfsa-move-targets-savvy-investors/article4215495/
[2] http://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/personal-finance/taxman-may-forgive-tfsa-rule-breakers/article1373287/
[3] http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/doubling-tfsa-limit-will-only-help-wealthy-study-argues-1.2967796
fields.summary:
The Tax-Free Savings Account (TFSA) is a special type of account which allows Canadian residents to contribute after-tax funds up to a yearly contribution limit. Any earnings within the TFSA account (such as interest or capital gains) are tax-free. The individual can choose to withdraw funds from his/her TFSA at any time without being subject to tax on the withdrawals.
The Conservative government has proposed to dobule the TFSA contribution limit from the current $5,500 per year to $11,000 per year.

fields.title: Net Neutrality
fields.text:
#Background#
The term Net Neutrality was originally coined by professor Tim Wu in 2003 (http://www.jthtl.org/content/articles/V2I1/JTHTLv2i1_Wu.PDF). However, the debate on Net Neutrality was ongoing prior to that. Advocates for Net Neutrality are concerned that ISPs may use their control over the network infrastructure to block or otherwise deteriorate access to content, services or websites which are competitors to, or deemed undesirable by, the ISP.
Critics of Net Neutrality claim that network management is needed in order to ensure Quality of Service and to prioritize critical applications such as VoIP telephony or email, over less critical ones, like peer-to-peer networks.

# Actors #
 - **Internet Service Providers**: Companies which connect retail customers to the Internet. Examples include Comcast, AT&T, Time Warner Cable, Rogers, etc.
 - **Transit Service Providers**: Companies, sometimes ISPs or hosting providers, which interconnect ISPs. They are responsible for the backbone of the Internet. When content moves from a hosting provider to an ISP, the Transit Service Providers may collect fees. Examples include Cogent Communications, Hurricane Electric, Level 3 Communications, etc.
 - **Established Content Providers**: Include Netflix, Amazon, Google, etc. These are large companies, responsible for the majority of content carried over the Internet.
 - **Government**: The Government can impose a law on ISPs, requiring Net Neutrality. The main interest of the government is to ensure fair access to content, while promoting economic activity.
 - **Alternative Content Providers**: Services like Vimeo, Mega, Popcorn Time and other emerging providers. They may be unable to enter in agreements with ISPs due to lack of funding or legal impediments.
 - **Internet Users**: Ordinary people want to maximize their access to content and connection quality, while keeping prices low.

# Impacts #
## Social Impacts ##
**Content Monopoly**. Alternative content providers are concerned that ISPs may use their control over the network to “lock-out” competing services or those unable to enter into traffic shaping agreements.

**Censorship**. Internet users are worry of the impact that control over access to content may have on democracy and freedoms.

**Quality of Service**. Internet providers claim that some popular content providers cause saturation of the network and degrade the Internet service for all users. Some users are concerned that degraded network performance may impact essential communications services such as access to 911 over VoIP lines.

**Inequality**. Some content providers claim that the design of Internet protocols already imposes inequality by favouring non time-sensitive applications, such as large file downloads, over real time services like VoIP or multiplayer games. They argue that network management techniques level the playing field for time-sensitive applications.

## Economic Impacts ##
**Internet Service Innovations**. ISPs are concerned that a few content providers utilize most of the available network bandwidth without paying a proportional access fee. Thus, they claim that further innovations in Internet services would be hindered unless tiered Internet access is introduced.

**“Double dipping”**. Some content providers are worried that without Net Neutrality ISPs may charge twice for transmitting the same content: once as Transit Service Providers when content leaves the source, and a second time as ISPs when content reaches the subscriber.

**Tiered service**. Consumers are concerned that, without Net Neutrality, ISPs may introduce tiered service requiring them to pay extra for access to the content they are already subscribing to.

**Interference with free market**. Critics of Net Neutrality claim that government intervention impacts the free market’s ability to reach price equilibrium based on supply and demand at the various levels of service quality.

# In Perspective #
- Some providers in the developing world offer what is known as “Free Zones”, meaning that content providers have entered in an agreement with the ISP to cover fees associated with accessing the content over the ISP’s network (Lily Hay Newman (21 Jan 2014). "Net Neutrality Is Already in Trouble in the Developing World". Slate. Retrieved 18 Nov 2014).

- In December 2009, a major US ISP (Comcast) admitted to applying traffic shaping practices against BitTorrent traffic on its network and agreed to pay up to $16 Million USD as a settlement (Duncan, Geoff (23 December 2009). "Comcast to Pay $16 Million for Blocking P2P Applications". Digital Trends. Retrieved 23 December 2009.)

- The French ISP Orange has reached an agreement with Google, which stipulates that Google reimburses Orange for YouTube traffic (which amounts to about 50% of all traffic on the Orange network) (Robertson, Adi (2013-01-19). "French ISP Orange says it's making Google pay to send traffic over its network". The Verge. Retrieved 14 January 2014.)

- Some services, like Xbox gaming and IPTV, already receive preferential treatment over the network of US ISP Comcast. (Brendan Greeley (21 Jun 2012). "Comcast 'Invents' Its Own Private Internet". Bloomberg. Retrieved 18 Nov 2014.)

- Netflix, a major US video content provider, has established peering agreements with US ISPs Comcast and Verizon. It is debatable whether peering agreements are a violation of Net Neutrality, however they were reached in response to deteriorated performance of access to Netflix content over the ISPs’ networks. (Waniata, Ryan. "Comcast Jumps up in Netflix Speed Rankings after Payola-style Agreement." Digital Trends. N.p., 14 Apr. 2014. Web. 15 Aug. 2014.) (Waniata, Ryan. "Netflix Calls Verizon out on the Big Red Screen [Update: Netflix Backs Off]." Digital Trends. N.p., 9 June 2014. Web. 15 Aug. 2014.)
fields.summary:
Net Neutrality is a principle requiring Internet Service Providers (ISP) to treat all content on the Internet equally (http://web.archive.org/web/20080901084929/http://www.google.com/help/netneutrality.html). ISPs may not apply traffic shaping or other network management techniques based on the type of content or the parties that are exchanging it. Proponents of Net Neutrality claim that in this respect it is similar to a telephone call: a phone company must treat all calls equally, regardless of what is being said or by whom.
There is a debate, particularly in the United States, whether the government should enact the Net Neutrality principle as a law.

fields.title: Bill C-13, Protecting Canadians from Online Crime Act
fields.text:
# Background #
A central nominal goal of Bill C-13 is to criminalize cyberbullying [1], which the Canadian Bar Association identifies as an 'Obvious legislative "gap"' [1]. In order to collect data, authorities must suspect that a crime has or will be committed, and that the information will assist in the crime's investigation. 

The bill establishes (in section 162.1) that sharing "intimate images" of a person, when the person in the image has not consented to the sharing, is an offense punishable by imprisonment for not more than 5 years.  Although the bill has been described (by Peter MacKay) as intended to protect children and youth from online predators, existing Criminal Code provisions (section 163.1 - Child Pornography) already criminalize the mere posession of such images, with harsher penalty.  Therefore, this bill only extends the provisions against the use of intimate images involving adults [1].

Section 162.1 also does not establish the need for malicious intent.  This means that in a hypothetical situation where Mr. Smith lends his laptop to Mr. Jones, Mr. Smith might be liable for having shared intimate images of him and his wife, even though they are in a deep folder marked "private", and he did not think that Mr. Jones would look there [1]. Other possibilities exist, and arise wording in section 162.1 which permits wide interpretation [1].  This also exposes the media, such as photojournalists, to criminal sanction for publishing compromising images of celebrities or politicians [1].

The Bar proposed other amendments to encourage a focus on cyberbullying and proportionate sentencing [1].  Further, they warn against excessive reliance on law to handle cyberbullying committed by youth, which may be less effective than education and other preventative measures [1]. 

Bill C-13 goes far beyond cyberbullying, and instead describes provisions for the search and seizure of Internet Data, revisiting "lawful access" legislation, which has previously been controversial [1].  The Canadian Bar Association recommended splitting the Bill into two bills, one which addresses cyberbullying, and the other to address lawful access legislation.

The Canadian Association of the Bar acknowledges the concern of the Canadian Government, but has recommended that enhancements to state power which infringe on privacy should be coupled with effective oversight mechanisms. [1]

Section 487.012 provides the power for police officers to make "preservation demands", without any judicial authorization, which requires a person to preserve (i.e. not delete) data, if the officer has reasonable grounds to suspect that a crime has or will be committed, and that the data will assist in the investigation, or that a crime under any Foreign law has or will be committed.  In the case of crimes in Canada, preservation would be for 21 days, while for foreign laws, for 90 days.  The CBA recommended reducing these periods to only cover a reasonable amount of time needed to get judicial authorization, and that preservation demands should only be applicable for crimes according to foreign laws which would also be crimes in Canada.  The Act does not require written records to be kept. (CBA recommends this be required.)

Subsection 5 of 487.012 gives officers the ability to impose unlimited conditions on preservation demands.  According to CBA, such conditions could prevent a party from exercising lawful rights, and such restrictions should only be imposed by a court of competent jurisdiction.

The bill empowers judges to issue production orders for tracking data (such as GPS data), information identifying financial account holders, and the use of tracking devices, but with a lower threshold than previously existed -- 
only requiring that the judge be satisfied that there are reasonable grounds to *suspect* (as opposed to believe) that on offense has or will be committed.

Section 492.2 updates laws which enabled officers to obtain telephone metadata to allow law enforcement to install "transmission data recorders" to capture metadata related to any kind of telecommunications.  Because of the richness of digital telecommunications, this could identify far more detailed biographical information about the individual, and so is a materially more severe invasion of privacy.  Warrants to use a transmission data recorder also only need to be justified by reasonable grounds to *suspect* (as opposed to believe) that an offense has or will be committed.  Information that could be captured would include

 - the IP address of the originating computer and server (i.e. website) being communicated with
 - the computer program being used
 - the protocol being used (identifying whether the person is viewing a website, using videoconferencing, etc)
 - whether the transmission was completed

This would enable, for example, to tell whether a person had been communicating on a regular basis with a particular health professional, or accessing a particular online service.

# Actors #
- CSEC
- Government of Canada

# Impacts #
## Culture ##
- The criminalization of cyberbullying would enable law enforcement to take action against people committing cyberbullying, and might reduce its prevalence.u 

# References #
[1] Commentary by the Canadian Bar Association ([pdf](http://www.google.ca/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=4&ved=0CDQQFjAD&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cba.org%2Fcba%2Fsubmissions%2Fpdf%2F14-33-eng.pdf&ei=Lk3cVJm9DoagNuCTgbAG&usg=AFQjCNHfIQ7iJmSssJ-kyhHJvOqwUoLRGg&sig2=A7dmQIKgYQnp9SzNteMAOw&bvm=bv.85761416,d.eXY))
fields.summary: A central nominal goal of Bill C-13 is to criminalize cyberbullying. The bill introduces new powers for surveillance, on a standard of reasonable suspicion.  The specific surveillance practices that the bill enables are unclear, but appear to cover the installation of hardware at Internet gateways, enabling deep-packet inspection of any through-traffic.

fields.title: Bill C-51 Anti-terrorism Act, 2015
fields.text:
# Background #

## "Terrorism offence" and "Terrorist propaganda" ##
It is important to understand the meaning of "terrorism offences", and other related ideas.  Many concerns about bill C-51 have been raised due to the notion of terrorism being too broad. The definition of "terrorism" in the Criminal Code includes not only acts of violence, but also any act committed for a political purpose that is intended to compel any government to do or refrain from doing something [5].

Terrorist propaganda, in turn, is defined in Bill C-51 as "advocating" or "promoting" a terrorism offence [7].  From the bill:

     “terrorist propaganda” means any writing, sign, visible 
     representation or audio recording that advocates or promotes the 
     commission of terrorism offences in general — other than an offence 
     under subsection 83.221(1) — or counsels the commission of a 
     terrorism offence. [7] 

It is, therefore, unclear how expansive "terrorist propaganda" is [1].  Bill C-51 also introduces the notion of actions that "undermin[e] the security of Canada or its economic or financial stability", which might be interpreted broadly [6][7].


## Lower threshold for evidence ##
In various other places, with respect to legislature relating to terrorist activities, the standard of evidence has been reduced from a reasonable belief that acts will be committed, to a reasonable belief that acts *may* be committed [7].  Bill C-51 allows for the detainment, without warrant, of a person who "may" commit a terrorist act, for a limited period of time if it is not practical to obtain a warrant first.  This period has been extended from three to seven days [].  



## Criminalization of terrorist propaganda ##
Bill C-51 introduces new laws prohibiting the "advocacy" or "promotion" of terrorism offences.  Section 83.221(1) appears to have drawn the most concern from critics:

     Every person who, by communicating statements, knowingly advocates or promotes 
     the commission of terrorism offences in general — other than an offence under this 
     section — while knowing that any of those offences will be committed or being 
     reckless as to whether any of those offences may be committed, as a result of such 
     communication, is guilty of an indictable offence and is liable to imprisonment 
     for a term of not more than five years. [7]




## Removal of terrorist propaganda ##
Bill C-51 also enables judges to order the deletion material deemed to be terrorist propaganda from computer systems [1][7].  The originator of the material can appear before the judge to represent themselves and appeal the decision [7].
Currently, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) runs a program entitled Countering Violent Extremism (CVE) which attempts to connect with people who hold radical views and prevent them from becoming violent [5]. However, the criminalization of terrorist propaganda might interfere with the availability of intelligence that would occur naturally on social media. 




## New powers for CSIS ##
CSIS currently only has the ability to investigate, and must pass information to the RCMP, who can then act on it.  Bill C-51 will give CSIS the power to actively interfere in order to prevent terrorism offences, by taking certain actions, including [4]:
    - cancelling travel reservations made by suspected extremists,
    - blocking shipments to Canada of material that could be used in a terrorist attack,
    - rendering shipments of suspected terrorist-related material unusable.




## Privacy ##
Bill c-51 allows for the sharing of information between government institutions, when such sharing is needed for said institutions to fulfil their mandates, and when it is a matter of national security [7].  Judges can order Internet service providers (ISPs) to provide identifying information of the sources of terrorist propaganda so that they may be located [4].  Recall that in June 2014, the Supreme Court ruled that a warrant is required for law enforcement to obtain identifying information about Canadians from ISPs [1][2][3].



## No-fly list ##
The so-called "no-fly list" is a secret list of individuals that may be prevented from travelling, or who are subject to screening, by the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness.  Airline carriers are legally required to cooperate in this respect.

Bill C-51 lowers the threshold for evidence needed to put people onto the "no-fly list" and establishes the appeal process for individuals who have been prevented from travelling [7][8]





# Impacts #
## Readiness #
Allowing CSIS to use the information it has to take action to prevent terrorist plots will reduce the response time, and will likely lead to more effective protection against terrorist activities [4].

By rendering the promotion/advocacy of terrorist propaganda illegal, a valuable source of intelligence could be suppressed, driving actual terrorist plots underground. This could lead to less effective protection against terrorist activities [6].


## Democracy ##
By lowering the standard of evidence, the new laws may lead to self-censorship or undue and unnecessary surveillance of those expressing political dissent [1].  The vague definitions of "advocating" and "promoting" terrorism may lead to "persecutory overreach" [5].

It has been suggested that protests and civil disobedience could be construed as undermining the security of Canada, or its economic or financial stability [6].  As an example, consider a demonstration by environmentalists peacefully obstructing work on a new pipeline installation [6]. 


## Culture ##
Material considered to be "terrorist propaganda" could be partially removed from the Internet information normally accessible to Canadians.
Political and artistic expression "near the fringe" may be self-censored, since it is not clear what constitutes "terrorist propaganda" [1].

The uncertainty created by Bill C-51 may make it more difficult for law enforcement to engage with people who are suspected to be susceptible to radicalization, for example, as part of the CVE program, because those people might be more fearful of law enforcement [5]. 

The wide interpretation of "terrorism advocacy" could hamper the freedom of expression.  Consider cases in other countries, in which revolutionary and violent struggle exists with a regime widely recognized to be oppressive: due to the broad definition of "terrorism" in the criminal code, vocalizing support for rebels could be considered the advocacy of "terrorism" [6].



# In perspective #
 - Existing legislation allows a judge to order the removal of "hate propaganda" and child pornography [1].
 - In the UK, in 2010, more than 65 000 pieces of unlawful terrorism-related content was removed, 80% of which was from jihadist groups from Iraq and Syria [1].
 - The UK has no requirement for public disclosure about how often and what content is blocked and/or removed. [1]
 - In the UK, the government reached an agreement with ISPs to voluntarily block content from outside the UK, at the request of the UK counterterrorism unit, without court order [1]. 
 - In Australia, ISPs and websites can be compelled to remove content, and action can be taken against them if they refuse.  For content outside the country, the ASIO or federal police can order ISPs or websites to block the content, without court order [1].
 - Relative to France, the USA, Australia, and the UK, Canada's anti-terrorism legislation is "less invasive" [4].

# References #
[1] [CBC. Bill C-51 aims to 'remove terrorist propaganda' from Internet](http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/bill-c-51-aims-to-remove-terrorist-propaganda-from-internet-1.2938935)  
[2] [CBC. Internet users' privacy upheld by Canada's top court](http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/internet-users-privacy-upheld-by-canada-s-top-court-1.2673823)  
[3] [Supreme Court judgment: R v. Spensor](http://scc-csc.lexum.com/scc-csc/scc-csc/en/item/14233/index.do)  
[4] [The National Post. *S.A. McCartan: Virtually all of Canada’s allies give their spy agencies powers to prevent terror. Why not us?*](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/03/s-a-mccartan-virtually-all-of-canadas-allies-give-their-spy-agencies-powers-to-prevent-terror-why-not-us/)  
[5] [It’s easy to imagine Bill C-51 actually undermining Canada’s anti-terrorism strategy](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/13/national-post-view-its-easy-to-imagine-bill-c-51-actually-undermining-canadas-anti-terrorism-strategy/)  
[6] [Terry Glavin: A whiff of totalitarianism in Bill C-51](http://news.nationalpost.com/2015/02/11/terry-glavin-a-whiff-of-totalitarianism-in-bill-c-51/)  
[7] [Bill C-51, Anti-terrorism Act, 2015](http://www.parl.gc.ca/HousePublications/Publication.aspx?Language=E&Mode=1&DocId=6932136&File=32#1)  
[8] [Anti-terrorism powers: What's in the legislation?](http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/anti-terrorism-powers-what-s-in-the-legislation-1.2937964)

It expands CSIS's powers, permitting CSIS not only to investigate, but to actively disrupt terrorist activities.  Bill C-51 allows for the sharing of personally identifying information about Canadians, between government institutions, when it is a matter of national security.  Bill C-51 reduces the standard of evidence for taking enforcement action against terrorist offences that are believed will occur.  It renders the "promotion" or "advocacy" of terrorist offences illegal.

For instance, the abnormally low interest rate has allowed a large number of people to take mortgages. If the interest rates recover, a TFSA could save home-owners who are facing unexpected increase in the payments for their home.

[1] http://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/personal-finance/tfsa-move-targets-savvy-investors/article4215495/
[2] http://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/personal-finance/taxman-may-forgive-tfsa-rule-breakers/article1373287/

fields.summary:
The Tax-Free Savings Account (TFSA) is a special type of account which allows Canadian residents to contribute after-tax funds up to a yearly contribution limit. Any earnings within the TFSA account (such as interest or capital gains) are tax-free. The individual can choose to withdraw funds from his/her TFSA at any time without being subject to tax on the withdrawals.
The Conservative government has proposed to dobule the TFSA contribution limit from the current $5,500 per year to $11,000 per year.

fields.title: Doubling TFSA contribution limits
fields.text:
#Background#
The TFSA account was first introduced in 2009 to encourage Canadians to save. Originally the account allowed for contributions of up to $5,000 per year. 

# Actors #
 - **Government**: The Government wants to provide incentive for Canadians to save money. At the same time it has to balance the budget and ensure that no group of Canadians are unfairly benefiting from the regulations. 
 - **Banks**: Banks benefit by holding TFSA deposits because the rules of this account discourage Canadians from withdrawing money on a regular basis. When money is withdrawn from a TFSA account, the contribution room is not freed up until the following year. By having longer-term accounts banks can invest the funds in lucrative mortgages or credit card offers, while giving only a negligible portion of the earnings as interest back to the TFSA account holder.
 - **Average Canadians**: The average working class Canadian benefits from TFSA accounts by means of tax-free interest and incentive to keep healthy financial discipline.
 - **Savvy investors and traders**: Savvy investors and traders are able to exploit the full potential of a TFSA. The TFSA is a very flexible investment vehicle, particularly if used as a self-directed account. It can hold a large variety of securities and financial instruments, similar to a RRSP account. The few exclusions relate to shares in companies of which the TFSA account holder has controlling role. Savvy individuals with access to highly lucrative investments have a virtually unlimited potential to earn tax-free income by re-investing earnings within the TFSA account.

# Impacts #
## Unfair advantages ##
**Tax avoidance**. When the TFSA was first introduced, savvy investors and traders took unfair advantage of the weak penalties for over-contribution and unqualified investments. The original penalty for over contribution was only 1% per month (and only on the over-contributions). Wealthy investors with access to investments with high returns were over-contributing $100,000 or more, paying the 1% penalty and still keeping all returns as tax-free income. Furthermore, initially the penalty for purchasing prohibited investments inside a TFSA (such as the shares of a company you control) was simply forfeiting the purchase. I.e., investors with questionable morality were allowed to keep any capital gains from breaking the rules, without paying tax[1].
While the rules have since changed to prevent the most obvious tax avoidance schemes, questions still remain about what other opportunities for abuse are being exploited.

**Unequal opportunities**. In 2010 big banks held 75% of Tax-Free Savings Accounts[2]. That is to say, 75% of accounts were giving their owners only the marginal interest rate that the big banks offer. At the same time, the remaining 25% of TFSAs were self-directed or held by other institutions, offering lucrative investments with limitless tax exemption to those in the know. Fast-forward to 2012, less than 16% of TFSA account holders under 60 years old had reached the $5,500 contribution limit[3]. I.e., only 16% of the economically active Canadian residents with TFSA accounts have enough spare income to reach the $5,500 TFSA contribution limit. If the limit is doubled, then, fewer than 16% of working Canadians will be able to benefit from this tax-break.

## Economic Impacts ##
**Loss of tax income**. By having no limits on the types of investments in a TFSA, the government in power leaves an unpredictable tax loss for future governments. The amount of tax wealthy investors and knowledgeable traders will not pay into future budgets depends only on their luck and skills. Doubling the contribution limit has cumulative impact on the tax loss, as any earnings can be re-invested freely.

**Reduced economic activity**. Encouraging Canadians to invest up to $11,000 of their yearly income in a savings account and penalizing them (by means of lost contribution room) for withdrawals, may negatively impact local businesses as less money will be circulating in the economy. This will put deflationary pressure on an economy that is already struggling to achieve inflation targets.

**Cushion for rate hike**. The TFSA can have a positive impact on the economy by providing a cushion for future changes that may take households by surprise. For instance, the abnormally low interest rate has allowed a large number of people to take mortgages. If the interest rates recover, a TFSA could save home-owners who are facing unexpected increase in the payments for their home.

# References #
[1] [The Globe and Mail, *TFSA move targets savvy investors*, 2009](http://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/personal-finance/tfsa-move-targets-savvy-investors/article4215495/)  
[2] [The Globe and Mail, *Taxman may forgive TFSA rule breakers*, 2010](http://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/personal-finance/taxman-may-forgive-tfsa-rule-breakers/article1373287/)  
[3] [CBC, *Doubling TFSA limit will only help wealthy, study argues*, 2015](http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/doubling-tfsa-limit-will-only-help-wealthy-study-argues-1.2967796)

fields.summary: The Tax-Free Savings Account (TFSA) allows Canadian residents to contribute after-tax funds up to a yearly contribution limit. Funds in a TFSA account can be invested, for example, in stocks, and any interest or capital gains are tax-free. The individual can choose to withdraw funds from his/her TFSA at any time without being subject to tax on the withdrawals. The Conservative government has proposed to double the TFSA contribution limit from the current $5,500 per year to $11,000 per year.  TFSA accounts create great opportunities for savvy investers, while the benefit ordinary Canadians are comparatively modest.

fields.title: Canada's involvement in Syria and Iraq
fields.text:
# Background #

## Origins of ISIS ##
ISIS, the Islamic State of Syria and Iraq, also goes by the names ISIL, the Islamic State of Syria and the Levant, and simply IS, Islamic State.  ISIS is a jihadist group that grew in the wake of the Iraq war.  After the US and UK overthrew the oppressive autocrat Saddam Hussein, regional, ethnic, and religious conflicts came to the fore [6].  Furthermore, the militias that the US had armed and allied with to defeat Saddam Hussein were themselves 

It originally spun off from Al-Qaeda.  Seeking to create an Islamic state in Iraq, instability within Syria has created an opportunity for it take territory there.  Currently it occupies a large territory straddling the border between Iraq and Syria [3].  ISIS seeks to take over Iraq and Syria to create a unified Islamic state based on a strict interpretation of the Koran. [3]

## Conflict in Syria ##
The Syrian Government is headed by president Bashar Al-Assad.  Assad is an oppressive autocrat who has repeatedly used the Syrian army to kill dissenters and protesters.  Under Assad's leadership, the government has bombed its own people, and is alleged to have used chemical weapons on them as well.

The oppressive reign of Assad has led to the emergence of rebel groups that seek to overthrow and replace the government.  The Free Syrian Army is one such group, consisting of defectors from the Syrian Army.  The National Coalition of Syrian Revolution and Opposing Forces, is only nominally united [10]. The BBC estimates that there are up to 1000 different rebel groups in Syria.  Although they have a common goal to overthrow Assad, their are bitter rivalries between them [10].  Many of the opposition forces fighting Assad and ISIS are almost as brutal: certain opposition militia have engaged in torture, the use of child soldiers, and mass killings [10].  Meanwhile, the crimes against humanity committed by Assad's regime arguably surpass even ISIS itself [10].

## Canada's involvement in Syria ##


## Actors ##
*[Note these are the decision makers relative to Canada's involvement, not the many players in the complex situation in Syria.  I.e. PM, leader of opposition, etc, other influencers such as advisors]*

## Impacts ##

*[How does this affect our image abroad?]*

# Background #

## Origins of ISIS ##
ISIS, the Islamic State of Syria and Iraq, also goes by the names ISIL, the Islamic State of Syria and the Levant, and simply IS, Islamic State.  ISIS is a jihadist group that grew in the wake of the Iraq war.  After the US and UK overthrew the oppressive autocrat Saddam Hussein, regional, ethnic, and religious conflicts came to the fore [6].  Furthermore, the militias that the US had armed and allied with to defeat Saddam Hussein were themselves 

It originally spun off from Al-Qaeda.  Seeking to create an Islamic state in Iraq, instability within Syria has created an opportunity for it take territory there.  Currently it occupies a large territory straddling the border between Iraq and Syria [3].  ISIS seeks to take over Iraq and Syria to create a unified Islamic state based on a strict interpretation of the Koran. [3]

## Conflict in Syria ##
The Syrian Government is headed by president Bashar Al-Assad.  Assad is an oppressive autocrat who has repeatedly used the Syrian army to kill dissenters and protesters.  Under Assad's leadership, the government has bombed its own people, and is alleged to have used chemical weapons on them as well.

The oppressive reign of Assad has led to the emergence of rebel groups that seek to overthrow and replace the government.  The Free Syrian Army is one such group, consisting of defectors from the Syrian Army.  The National Coalition of Syrian Revolution and Opposing Forces, is only nominally united [10]. The BBC estimates that there are up to 1000 different rebel groups in Syria.  Although they have a common goal to overthrow Assad, their are bitter rivalries between them [10].  Many of the opposition forces fighting Assad and ISIS are almost as brutal: certain opposition militia have engaged in torture, the use of child soldiers, and mass killings [10].  Meanwhile, the crimes against humanity committed by Assad's regime arguably surpass even ISIS itself [10].

fields.title: Canada's involvement in Syria and Iraq
fields.text:
# Background #

## Origins of ISIS ##
ISIS, the Islamic State of Syria and Iraq, also goes by the names ISIL, the Islamic State of Syria and the Levant, and simply IS, Islamic State.  ISIS is a jihadist group that grew in the wake of the Iraq war.  After the US and UK overthrew the oppressive autocrat Saddam Hussein, regional, ethnic, and religious conflicts came to the fore [6].  Furthermore, the militias that the US had armed and allied with to defeat Saddam Hussein were themselves brutal warlards, who, after the defeat of Saddam Hussein, turned on one another and the US.

ISIS is a splinter group of Al-Qaeda.  Seeking to create an Islamic state in Iraq, instability within Syria has created an opportunity for it take territory there.  Currently it occupies a large territory straddling the border between Iraq and Syria [3].  ISIS seeks to take over Iraq and Syria to create a unified Islamic state based on a strict interpretation of the Koran. [3]

## Conflict in Syria ##
The Syrian Government is headed by president Bashar Al-Assad.  Assad is an oppressive autocrat who has repeatedly used the Syrian army to kill dissenters and protesters.  Under Assad's leadership, the government has bombed its own people, and is alleged to have used chemical weapons on them as well.

The oppressive reign of Assad has led to the emergence of rebel groups that seek to overthrow and replace the government.  The Free Syrian Army is one such group, consisting of defectors from the Syrian Army.  The National Coalition of Syrian Revolution and Opposing Forces, is only nominally united [10]. The BBC estimates that there are up to 1000 different rebel groups in Syria.  Although they have a common goal to overthrow Assad, their are bitter rivalries between them [10].  Many of the opposition forces fighting Assad and ISIS are almost as brutal: certain opposition militia have engaged in torture, the use of child soldiers, and mass killings [10].  Meanwhile, the crimes against humanity committed by Assad's regime arguably surpass even ISIS itself [10].

## Canada's initial involvement in Syria ##
**Decision.** In October 2015, after assent by the house of Commons, the government approved the Canadian forces participation in a coalition effort to fight ISIS.  The coalition is US-led, and includes the UK, France, Australia, and many Arab countries [3].  More than 60 countries have joined the coalition [2].  

**Operations.** The coalition operates under the following limits [3]:
 - no ground fighting
 - use airstrikes to attack ISIS positions and disrupt supply lines

However, Canada's Joint Task Force 2, the elite special forces, were involved in training Kurdish soldiers in combat zones[3].  Only the US and its Arab allies have been active in Syria, Canada, and the other western members of the Coalition, have been active only in Iraq [3].

Canada's contribution to the effort consists of 600 soldiers, 6 CF-18s (plus one spare), two Aurora reconnaissance planes, and a Polaris aerial refueller [3].  Since 2 Nov, Canadian forces have flown CF-18s daily in a state of readiness to attack [3; 8].  Within the first two weeks of air operations, Canadian war planes destroyed 2 ISIS targets [1].  

Canadian forces operate under a strict no-civilian casualty policy, and will not strike a target unless the risk of civilian casualties is zero.

**Cost.** The first six months of deployment cost CAD$ 122 M.

**Effects.** As of Nov 02 2014, after three months of airstrikes by coalition forces, ISIS appeared undeterred [3].  ISIS Targets have become more difficult to find because they are increasingly hiding among civilian populations, where they are impossible to target without casualties [3].  ISIS has also increasingly shifted its forces to it's western front in Syria, which is outside of Canada's mandate, and that of the other Western allies except the US.  Shortly after Canada joined the effort, an ISIS spokesman called for attacks on all
inti-ISIS coalition forces, and specifically named Canada [2].

## Proposed extension of Canada's mandate ##
**Time extension.** Canada's participation in the fight against ISIS would be extended for one year, until March 2016.

**Geographical extension.** The government proposes to extend Canada's mandate to include airstrikes in Syria. 

## Actors ##
*[Note these are the decision makers relative to Canada's involvement, not the many players in the complex situation in Syria.  I.e. PM, leader of opposition, etc, other influencers such as advisors]*

## Impacts ##
### Relations ###
*[How will our involvement contribute to relations to our allies?]*
*[How does this affect our image abroad?]*

### Impacts in Syria ###
*[How will our involvement contribute to the situation in Syria.  What improvements could occur, as well as what unintended consequences may arise]*

### Social ###
*[Is it a good idea to be sending our young people over there?  What situation are they likely to meet.  Is the potential benefit worth it?]*
*[What can be said about our obligations to intervene?]*

fields.title: Canada's involvement in Syria and Iraq
fields.text:
# Background #

## ISIS ##
**Origins.** ISIS, the Islamic State of Syria and Iraq, also goes by the names ISIL, the Islamic State of Syria and the Levant, and simply IS, Islamic State.  ISIS is a jihadist group that grew in the wake of the Iraq war.  After the US and UK overthrew the oppressive autocrat Saddam Hussein, regional, ethnic, and religious conflicts came to the fore [6].  Furthermore, the militias that the US had armed and allied with to defeat Saddam Hussein were themselves brutal warlards, who, after the defeat of Saddam Hussein, turned on one another and the US.

ISIS is a splinter group of Al-Qaeda.  Seeking to create an Islamic state in Iraq, instability within Syria has created an opportunity for it take territory there.  Currently it occupies a large territory straddling the border between Iraq and Syria [3].  ISIS seeks to take over Iraq and Syria to create a unified Islamic state based on a strict interpretation of the Koran. [3]

**Identity.** ISIS proclaims that it represents Muslims of the world.  Despite their self-identification, they are shunned by the vast majority of muslims.  Nevertheless, adopting this posture, they proclaim that their enemies have declared war on Islam.  Their identification with Islam is the basis for their legitimacy internally and is used to recruit and radicalize new members. 

## Conflict in Syria ##
The Syrian Government is headed by president Bashar Al-Assad.  Assad is an oppressive autocrat who has repeatedly used the Syrian army to kill dissenters and protesters.  Under Assad's leadership, the government has bombed its own people, and is alleged to have used chemical weapons on them as well.

The oppressive reign of Assad has led to the emergence of rebel groups that seek to overthrow and replace the government.  The Free Syrian Army is one such group, consisting of defectors from the Syrian Army.  The National Coalition of Syrian Revolution and Opposing Forces, is only nominally united [10]. The BBC estimates that there are up to 1000 different rebel groups in Syria.  Although they have a common goal to overthrow Assad, their are bitter rivalries between them [10].  Many of the opposition forces fighting Assad and ISIS are almost as brutal: certain opposition militia have engaged in torture, the use of child soldiers, and mass killings [10].  Meanwhile, the crimes against humanity committed by Assad's regime arguably surpass even ISIS itself [10].

The Syrian war has cost tens of thousands of lives [2].

## Canada's initial involvement in Syria ##
**Decision.** In October 2015, after assent by the house of Commons, the government approved the Canadian forces participation in a coalition effort to fight ISIS.  The coalition is US-led, and includes the UK, France, Australia, and many Arab countries [3].  More than 60 countries have joined the coalition [2].  

**Operations.** The coalition operates under the following limits [3]:

 - no ground fighting
 - use airstrikes to attack ISIS positions and disrupt supply lines

However, Canada's Joint Task Force 2, the elite special forces, were involved in training Kurdish soldiers in combat zones[3].  Only the US and its Arab allies have been active in Syria, Canada, and the other western members of the Coalition, have been active only in Iraq [3].

Canada's contribution to the effort consists of 600 soldiers, 6 CF-18s (plus one spare), two Aurora reconnaissance planes, and a Polaris aerial refueller [3].  Since 2 Nov, Canadian forces have flown CF-18s daily in a state of readiness to attack [3; 8].  Within the first two weeks of air operations, Canadian war planes destroyed 2 ISIS targets [1].  

Canadian forces operate under a strict no-civilian casualty policy, and will not strike a target unless the risk of civilian casualties is zero.

**Cost.** The first six months of deployment cost CAD$ 122 M.

**Effects.** As of Nov 02 2014, after three months of airstrikes by coalition forces, ISIS appeared undeterred [3].  ISIS Targets have become more difficult to find because they are increasingly hiding among civilian populations, where they are impossible to target without casualties [3].  ISIS has also increasingly shifted its forces to it's western front in Syria, which is outside of Canada's mandate, and that of the other Western allies except the US.  Shortly after Canada joined the effort, an ISIS spokesman called for attacks on all
inti-ISIS coalition forces, and specifically named Canada [2].

## Proposed extension of Canada's mandate ##
**Time extension.** Canada's participation in the fight against ISIS would be extended for one year, until March 2016.

**Geographical extension.** The government proposes to extend Canada's mandate to include airstrikes in Syria. 



## The case for intervention ##
Some people argue that earlier intervention in Iraq and Syria could have avoided such a decline to chaos that enabled ISIS to flourish [2]. 

# Actors #
*[Note these are the decision makers relative to Canada's involvement, not the many players in the complex situation in Syria.  I.e. PM, leader of opposition, etc, other influencers such as advisors]*

# Impacts #
## Relations ##
There is a sense of responsibility to join with our allies in fighting ISIS.  Although there is no clear path toward stability in the Syria-Iraq region, ISIS is universally seen as the most violent and menacing group, and there is a general sense that ISIS must be resisted by countries who have the means.  Failing to engage would probably be seen by our allies as a fairly serious omission and a neglect of our moral duty.

## Impacts in Syria ##
While the expansion of ISIS surely leads to enormous atrocity, there is no clear path to stability in these areas.  The other groups in the region, who vie for power, are almost equally brutal and fighting ISIS tacitly supports these groups.  If ISIS is significantly degraded, it is not clear that people in Syria and Iraq will be any better off, since they face similar treatment by other groups. 

## Social ##
*[Is it a good idea to be sending our young people over there?  What situation are they likely to meet.  Is the potential benefit worth it?]*
*[What can be said about our obligations to intervene?]*

# Actors #
*[Note these are the decision makers relative to Canada's involvement, not the many players in the complex situation in Syria.  I.e. PM, leader of opposition, etc, other influencers such as advisors]*

# Impacts #
